'''10 Years of Minecraft''' is a [[DLC]] map released on May 9, 2019 on both ''[[Java Edition]]'' and ''[[Bedrock Edition]]'', celebrating the [[10th Anniversary]] of ''Minecraft''.

== Summary ==
=== The Vault ===
Players begin the map in a [[desert]], outside a [[desert pyramid]] marked by the 10th anniversary logo. Right beside the entrance are two [[chests]], containing 54 total unique "Anniversary Golden [[Minecarts]]," which the player can use inside on a [[track]] that recaps the last ten years of Java Edition updates. At the end of the track is a collection of numbered [[buttons]], with another chest containing a [[map]] and [[book]], labeled ''The Vault'' and credited to BlockWorks. Inside is an explanation of the surrounding area, an expansive locked door into the Vault itself.

To open it, the code is 170509. Once the combination is input, the door will open between both sets of buttons, revealing a fancy, dimly lit museum with a directory immediately visible. Beside it are two stairways, leading down to another minecart track that takes the player to the Mob Gardens. The first room of the museum itself is split between inorganic blocks, such as [[stone]] and [[gravel]], and organic blocks, such as [[coral]] and [[cacti]]. Chests containing books explaining each block in detail are placed about. In the center of the room is a [[gray stained glass]] floor, showing another recreation of the Minecraft 10th anniversary logo below.

At the north end of the room is a large quartz staircase, leading up to the second floor with an array of functional blocks, such as [[crafting table]]s and [[sponges]]. Unlike the preceding floor, this area is much more angular and adorned with [[end rods]], with [[stained glass pane]] railings over holes giving a look at the bottom. Also different on this floor is that the blocks are grouped into categories, in the form of utility blocks and mechanisms. Behind the staircase is a small room, labeled ''Minecraft: A History'', where players can find a condensed history of the franchise surrounding [[birch]] trees. These include Minecraft's player count,  the release of [[Lego Minecraft]], the release of [[Minecraft Story Mode]], the founding of the [[Minecraft Marketplace]], and various [[Minecon]]s.

A few blocks away from the first stairway is another, leading up to a slanted display of "manufactured blocks," such as [[banners]]. Another collection of blocks reside southwest of this, giving a large view of all three floors of the Vault. Also present on the third floor are large [[cyan stained glass]] windows, designed to mimic [[diamond ore]].

=== Biomedomes ===
Located to the north of the Vault, the Biomedomes are blocked by an expansive puzzle, where the player must jump across several [[chunks]]. If they touch the incorrect chunk, they will be teleported back to the start. In order to cross, players will need to read a book given right before, and memorize the pattern given. Upon completing the challenge, the player will be able to access the Biomedomes proper, and are given a [[heavy weighted pressure plate]] that can warp them back to the Vault.

Marching up a grand flight of stairs, players will enter into a recreational [[plains]] [[village]], with a puzzle nearby. Inside a chest is a [[diamond shovel]] and book named Adventuring Time, tasking players with collecting a [[poppy]], [[dandelion]], [[melon slice]], [[carrots]], [[lily pad]], [[beetroots]], [[nether wart]], [[red mushroom]], [[chorus fruit]], and [[rose bush]]. The poppy and dandelion are plentiful throughout the village, while [[beetroot crops]] and can be found in nearby farms. [[Melons]] can be found in a [[jungle]] area not far from the farms, the lily pad in a [[swamp]] close to the prompt, mushroom in a [[flower pot]] in a [[witch hut]], and rose bush in a [[forest]] far from the other biomes. Other biomes featured are [[dark forest]]s and [[birch forest]]s, and inside them are chests, containing explanations of the biomes in question.

The plants from other dimensions can be found by {{control|swimming}} down the well in the village, which drops the player down an abrupt tunnel into a [[stronghold]] marked with yellow [[thing]] banners. The stronghold is split between two paths, the [[Nether]] to the right and [[End]] to the left. The Nether section is set in a large [[nether wastes]] biome, littered with [[torches]]. Patrolling the grounds are [[wither skeletons]] and [[blazes]], which will chase after the player as in [[survival mode]]. The nether wart will be found inside of a [[nether fortress]], which will require a lengthy fight with the mobs.

The End section is a combination of the inner and outer End, beginning with a recreation of the [[ender dragon]] arena with the [[ender dragon egg]] on top of the [[exit portal]]. Beyond that is an [[end city]], complete with [[shulkers]]. Uniquely, on the second floor is a shulker [[monster spawner]]. Climbing upwards, players will find two chests, one containing two [[diamonds]] and a [[stick]], the other two diamonds, a [[shulker shell]] and [[shulker box]]. At the very top is a chest containing a book on the outer islands of the End. [[Chorus plants]] can be found below.

Once all the plants are found, a second chest will generate beside the flower bed, containing an [[diamond sword|anniversary golden sword]].

=== The Academy ===
Located to the east of the Vault, players will have to solve a puzzle before entering the building itself. The starting area of the region is a strip of land lined with [[stone bricks]] and [[white concrete]], with a chest containing instructions. Players will have to decipher a message written in the Standard Galactic Alphabet, using a codec credited to [[Herobrine]]. Pressing a button will teleport the player to a [[barrier]] block above the area, revealing a large statue of a book with the text in question. At the very end of the area is a building in the shape of an [[enchanting table]], where they can input the answer using various levers above items, such as [[turtle shell]]s.

The message on the book translates to "I have a spine, front and back but bones and teeth are what I lack, on me you can write your name but first craft me with 3 sugar-cane." This teaches the player to pull the levers for books and [[sugar canes]], which will open stained glass gates, allowing entry into the Academy. Climbing up dark oak stairs, players can advance up on top of the enchanting table, and climb the [[enchanting book]] into the Academy, passing a directory and iron pressure plate that warps the player back to the Vault.

The Academy is a large building modeled after a college, with the first room to the left of the entrance being a cafeteria with a checkerboard floor pattern, and obscured to the right a classroom with [[oak planks]] for the floor and a [[green terracotta]] chalkboard. In the proceeding hallway are two bathrooms, marked light blue and pink with toilets made of [[snow layers]] and gray carpets, and mirrors made of banners. From there is another door into the cafeteria, and a splitting hallway to the east and south. To the east is a large statue of an [[agent]], with nearby exits to roads of [[dirt paths]]. To the south is a similar exit, leading to a fountain with a humanoid figure, as well as an indoor stairway lined with [[anvils]]. Immediately on the second floor are two more classrooms and bathrooms, though differently designed, with the bathroom being reachable through a one block wide wall.

Returning to the Agent statue, players can make a turn to the left and discover a large assortment of displays on school subjects, including Art & Design, History & Culture, Math, Science, Computer Science, and Language Arts. In front of these is another book, simply labeled Education, explaining [[Minecraft Education]]. Above the area is a large recreation of the game's former logo. To the right of the Agent statue are several actual agents, making a "special visit" to vanilla Minecraft, as explained in a book marked "Robot." In this area, players are tasked with programming the agents, leading them to a [[block of gold]]. Four of these puzzles are present, with [[diamond axe]]s and exclusive "Robot Controller" blocks being given to assist.

For the first puzzle, they player will simply need to replace a Robot Controller and rotate it to face the gold, which it is directly next to. If a robot controller is removed with an agent on it, it will die and need to be respawned by a nearby button. The second puzzle will be to the right, and require reorienting three blocks, first to face the south, west, and south again in an L-shape. The third puzzle counterclockwise will be similarly simple, requiring a U-shaped path path to be straightened. This and the fourth puzzle require the agent to be spawned manually, as opposed to the others which have it naturally. The final puzzle will be in a W-shape, requiring a more complicated order, with blocks ordered in the east, south, east, south, and west.

Upon completing the Robot Minigame, a chest will appear next to the introduction chest, rewarding the player with a special anniversary golden bow and 28 arrows. Behind the puzzle is a large floor map, telegraphing the locations of Block by Block projects across the world, and a book with the achievements of Block by Block.

=== Mob Gardens ===
[[File:Mob Gardens entrance.png|thumb|Entrance to the gardens.]]
Located to the south of the Vault, directly behind the entrance, Mob Gardens is preceded by a collection of oversized [[spawn eggs]] amongst a [[badlands]] biome. Inside players will find a book, explaining a series of riddles that will enable players to enter the garden proper. Inside the [[parrot]], [[creeper]], and [[enderman]] eggs are [[levers]], which open the path to the gardens. Players can climb into the eggs via [[ladders]], finding very little beside [[carpets]]. Once all three are pulled, players can transcend [[stone brick stairs]] up into the true Mob Garden, a  modern dome house many of the [[mobs]] of the time, adorned with stained glass windows of mobs such as [[pigs]] and [[Steve]]. Upon entering the garden, players will find another directory and a fast travel back to the Vault.

To the left of the entrance are exhibits of passive mobs, all noticeably larger than normal, beginning with [[tropical fish]], [[mules]], [[skeleton horses]], and [[villagers]]. Similar to the Vault, there are chests containing books explaining the mobs' behavior and lore. At the very end of the room are a circular display for [[parrots]] and [[bats]], with the chests a considerable distance away from the mobs. In the center of the museum is a large spire of [[water]], surrounded by neutral mobs such as [[llamas]] and [[spiders]]. The right wing is devoted to hostile mobs, with [[elder guardians]] inflicting [[mining fatigue]] upon approach. Similar to the left wing, at the end is a circular area featuring flying mobs, in this case the [[Wither]], a [[phantom]], a [[ghast]], and a [[blaze]]. Between both wings are spiral staircases up to catwalks above the displays.

Returning to the spire, curious players will be able to discover a hole in the center, revealing a secret basement in the form of a mysterious garden lined with [[polished diorite]]. Traveling down a wooden path will inevitably lead the player to collide with [[tripwires]] surrounded by [[skeleton skull]]s, which summon various enemies such as [[skeletons]], [[endermites]], [[vexes]], and [[vindicators]]. Traveling through sections themed around the End, Nether, an [[ocean monument]], the player will emerge in a chamber filled with banners of Herobrine, and be rewarded with eleven [[enchanted apples]], in the shape of the number 10.

=== The Museum of Redstone ===
Located to the west of the Vault, the Museum of Redstone is surrounded by a gigantic recreation of a circuit board. In order to enter the building, players will need to activate ten [[redstone lamps]], marked by a [[spruce]] device in the center. These lamps are activated by clicking ten levers in the area, on the sides of small structures, which contain [[redstone blocks]] and [[cobblestone walls]]. Upon opening the door, players can proceed into a [[polished andesite]] tunnel into a gigantic [[piston]], climbing a large flight of stairs up past a directory and arrive in a courtyard marked by statues composed of [[redstone blocks]].

The Museum itself is a large, open building made of terracotta and [[acacia]], surrounded by lamp fixtures made of floating pistons. Up another set of stairs, players will find a chest in front of a redstone device, containing a book tasking the player with lighting various blocks up. In the center of the room are several unlit lamps, which light up with your progress. To the left of the entrance room is a large hallway, containing tutorials for various redstone mechanisms, such as [[redstone torches]] and [[T flip-flop]]. Following a path modeled after a [[redstone wire]] will eventually lead to a lower floor, containing the Redstone Grove, a zoo area filled with [[_Jeb]] sheep and a redstone environment. The trees are [[redstone lamps]] on [[block of redstone]] trunks, abundant [[tulip|red tulips]], and [[redstone ore]]s scattered throughout every stone source. At the bottom is a book, explaining the lore of the grove in a poem.

In order to "light up the building," the player will need to interact with each of the tutorials. The lever, locking [[repeater]], and redstone torch, and T flip-flop lights can be completed with a simple {{control|use}}. For the button, they have to use a [[bow]] to shoot the button, which breaks in one use. The [[detector rail]] requires pushing the minecart on top of the detector, while the [[daylight detector]] can be solved by either turning it to detect shade or pulling a hidden lever on the ceiling to reveal sunlight. In the chest of the tripwire chest are 14 [[coal]] in the shape of a ten, with the book in the zero. Once all are activated at once, the player can progress to the right wing.

Similar to the left wing, the lever, AND gate, [[comparator]], puzzles can be solved with basic interaction. There are four [[comparator]] puzzles, the first requiring filling a chest with coal, the second uses a [[hopper]] that requires 160 coal, the third pulling several levers, and the fourth a specific lever out of six. The [[slime block]] puzzle needs the player to pull a middle lever and slightly obscured right lever. Also similar to the left wing is an attraction at the end of the wing, in this case an out of order elevator.{{More info}}

Upon completing every puzzle, a large double chest will be revealed, containing anniversary golden [[armor]]. Another activity the player can do is climb somewhat obscure stairways in the lobby, which will lead into an attic area with a large redstone contraption held up by [[cobblestone walls]]. Proceeding up another, spiral staircase will lead players into an observatory, revealing the device to be a [[TNT cannon]]. Before it is another chest, containing a book explaining some lore about the machine and [[chain boots]] enchanted with [[feather falling]] IV.

Another collection of stairs lie back on the first floor, positioned behind giant claws hung by the lamp puzzles. On the surface, they would appear to be a viewing area, similar to the catwalks in Mob Gardens. At the end are another set of stairs lined with [[acacia logs]], leading up to a gallery of various redstone machines. On the left wing are several "armouring machines," the first simply made of stone blocks, stone bricks, and dispensers. The second, labeled Armouring Machine 2.0, is a plate of [[blocks of iron]], with [[birch fence]] posts on the corners, and four dispensers surrounding [[soul sand]] in the center. On the right wing is a complex contraption made of multiple [[wool]] blocks, marked as out of order.

=== Golden Apples ===
In the corners of the map are six Golden Apples, structures in the shape of golden apples that are accessed through railways underneath the Vault. The first available is from the entrance to Mob Gardens, leading to the southwest apple. Inside each of the Golden Apples is a parkour challenge, leading to the top of the apple, where the player is rewarded with an enchanted golden apple. Once all six are completed, as well as any of the primary puzzles across the map, the player will be teleported "back to spawn" on a large platform, filled with cakes and containing a chest with several items.

Inside the chest are two [[music disc]]s, both of the song Happy Birthday. One is sung in English and sung by the employees of [[Mojang Studios]] in Redmond, while the other is in Swedish and from Stockholm. Opposite to those are a Special Anniversary Minecart and Special Minecart Key. The Minecart summons an entity when placed, which possesses an [[inventory]] with 12 slots, and can be ridden by putting the key in the saddle slot. While ridden, it allows the player to fly. Also on the platform is a creeper entity that dances, before turning into a large grass block, thanking the player for exploring the map.

|content=
Did you know Minecraft is being used in schools in over 115 countries around the world?

35 million students and educators have access to Minecraft: Education Edition, which uses Minecraft to teach, engage and inspire children across a huge range of subjects.

{{EntitySprite|Agent}} '''Robots'''{{Collapse
|content=
These little fellows are the Education Edition Code Builder robots. They don't normally live in this Minecraft platform, but since it's a special occasion they have made a special visit!

The robots are controlled by the blocks they are walking on. The direction of the arrow shows which direction the robot will move next.

You can break and rotate the green arrows using the pickaxe, but you cannot break the magenta arrows!

It is your task to help guide the robot towards the gold block, which will turn diamond when completed. Complete all 4 puzzles for your reward.
}}
{{ItemSprite|Map}} '''Block by Block'''{{Collapse
|content=
Block by Block began in 2012 with the radical idea of integrating the computer game Minecraft into public space planning to get community members more involved.

A collaboration between Mojang, Microsoft and UNHabitat, Block by Block allows everyone to have a say in the design of their local public space by using Minecraft as a collaborative design tool.

After a project location is selected, a 3-day workshop is held where community members share and discuss different ideas, before building them in Minecraft.

These Minecraft designs are then passed on to architects and local authorities who, with the help of Block by Block, build the real-world public space on the Minecraft model.
}}

1. Play a jingle and I'll flap and wriggle, but don't feed me chocolate - for my kind it's toxic!

2. Roses are red, violets are blue, give me a hug and I'll hug you back - BOOM!

3. They travel in hauntings, and are most certainly daunting. These tall chaps will disappear in a snap!
}}

Welcome to the Museum of Redstone!

=== The Vault ===

==== Natural Blocks ====
{{BlockSprite|air}} '''Air'''
{{Collapse|content=Air is generated in any space not occupied by a block. It is created and destroyed when blocks are removed and placed, so it cannot be kept in your inventory. Air‚Äôs presence often gets unnoticed and unappreciated.

Of course, that‚Äôs until you start to run out of it while swimming!|title=}}
{{BlockSprite|andesite}} '''Andesite'''
{{Collapse|content=Andesite is a decorative variant of stone that generates in the Overworld. It can be mined with a pickaxe or crafted with cobblestone or diorite}}
{{BlockSprite|diorite}} '''Diorite'''{{Collapse|content=Diorite is a decorative variant of stone that generates in the Overworld. It can be mined with a pickaxe or crafted by combining cobblestone with nether quartz.}}

{{BlockSprite|granite}} '''Granite'''{{Collapse|content=Granite is a decorative variant of stone that generates in the Overworld. It can be mined with a pickaxe or crafted by combining nether quartz with diorite.}}

{{BlockSprite|bedrock}} '''Bedrock'''
{{Collapse|content=Try as you might, this block is impossible to break unless you‚Äôre in Creative mode! You can find bedrock protecting you from the Void at the lowest five levels of the Overworld, and at the top and bottom of the Nether.

Bedrock was added to Minecraft on the tenth day of the game‚Äôs development. This means that bedrock was added to the game before water, lava, ores, and logs!}}
{{BlockSprite|bone-block}} '''Bone Block'''{{Collapse|content=I‚Äôve got a bone to pick with you! Bone blocks are decorative blocks that are naturally generated as a part of fossil structures found in desert and swamp biomes. Aside from decoration, they can be used to store bone meal.

Bone blocks can be mined with any pickaxe. If they are broken without a pickaxe, they drop nothing.}}

{{BlockSprite|clay}} '''Clay'''{{Collapse|content=Clay is obtained from clay blocks, which are found at the bottom of lakes, rivers, and swamps. Each clay block will drop four pieces of clay that can be crafted together.

There are many decorative uses for clay, and depending on whether you smelt the entire block or its individual pieces, you will gain different final products!}}

{{BlockSprite|coal-ore}} '''Coal Ore'''
{{Collapse|content=When mined with a pickaxe, coal ore will drop a single piece of coal. If it‚Äôs mined with a Fortune enchantment, the ore may drop an extra piece of coal per enchantment level, to a maximum of 4 coal with Futune III.

When used in a furnace as a fuel, it will last 80 seconds and smelt up to 8 items.

Can‚Äôt find coal? Burn some logs and you‚Äôll get charcoal, which has the same properties as coal!}}
{{BlockSprite|dirt}} '''Dirt'''
{{Collapse|content=Dirt! Making up most of the Overworld‚Äôs upper layers in various thicknesses, it lies unseen below a single layer of grass. It can be obtained by hand, but a shovel is the fastest way to dig it up.

Dirt also drops if you break grass, mycelium, or podzol without a Silk Touch tool.

Not sure what to do with all your dirt? Consider building a farm! Unless you plan on hunting or fishing all day, building a farm is the easiest way to create a renewable source of food.

So, while it may seem like a rather simple and common block, dirt is useful! Besides, how else are you supposed to survive the first night without building a dirt hut?}}
{{BlockSprite|coarse-dirt}} '''Coarse Dirt'''
{{Collapse|content=Coarse dirt is a variation of dirt that grass or mycelium will not spread on. Visually similar to regular dirt, it can be crafted by combining gravel and dirt.

It spawns naturally in the Overworld in all Giant Tree Taiga biomes, Wooded and Modified Wooded Badlands Plateaus, and Shattered Savanna Plateau biomes.}}
{{BlockSprite|podzol}} '''Podzol'''
{{Collapse|content=Podzol is a variant of dirt that generates in giant tree taiga and bamboo jungle biomes as well as their respective variants.

When broken, it will drop a regular block of dirt unless it is mined with Silk Touch. Podzol allows mushrooms to be placed on regardless of the light level, which allows for the growth of huge mushrooms.

Unlike grass and mycelium, however, podzol does not spread.}}
{{BlockSprite|grass-block}} '''Grass'''
{{Collapse|content=Along with cobblestone, grass was one of the first two blocks added to the game. This iconic block generates naturally in most biomes in the Overworld. 

If you right click it with a shovel, it will be turned into a grass path.

But grass is delicate. If a block is placed on top of it, or if it is broken by anything other than a Silk Touch tool, it will transform into regular dirt.

Then there are the mobs! Sheep like to eat it, and endermen like to steal it! At least the endermen will drop the grass block if they are killed - no Silk Touch required!

With all these ways for your grass to be messes around with, it sure is tough maintaining a perfect front lawn! Luckily, grass spreads to nearby dirt blocks, so it will grow back!}}
{{BlockSprite|mycelium}} '''Mycelium''' 
{{Collapse|content=Mycelium is a variant of dirt that generates instead of grass in mushroom fields biomes! If mycelium is mined with anything other than a Silk Touch tool, it will only drop dirt.

Endermen can pick up mycelium blocks, and will drop the block they are holding if killed. This is one way to obtain mycelium if you do not have Silk Touch! As with grass, mycelium is capable of spreading to nearby dirt blocks.

While mushrooms normally need low light levels to be placed, they can be placed on mycelium blocks in any light level. Huge mushrooms can also be grown on mycelium.}}
{{BlockSprite|cobblestone}} '''Cobblestone'''
{{Collapse|content=You‚Äôve reached the Stone Age! This incredibly common block is gained by mining stone with a pickaxe of any level. It is one tier better than wood, and required if you plan on crafting a furnace or advancing further in the game!

Don‚Äôt feel like leaving your home to gather cobblestone? Create your own cobblestone generator with a bucket of lava and a bucket of water! When flowing water and lava come into contact with one another another, a block of cobblestone will be created!}}
{{BlockSprite|mossy-cobblestone}} '''Mossy Cobble'''{{Collapse|content=A sure sign of a dungeon! Greener than its plain variant, mossy cobblestone is, well, covered in moss. This can be found in dungeons, jungle temples, the giant tree taiga biome, and in underwater ruins.

It can generate in pillager outpost watchtowers, as well as in plains, taiga, and snowy villages. Alternatively, it can be crafted by combining cobblestone with vines.}}

{{BlockSprite|cobweb}} '''Cobweb'''{{Collapse|content=Be careful not to get stuck in the cobwebs! If you get caught, you will get slowed down drastically until you are able to wiggle free. You can quickly break cobwebs with a sword to get string, or you can use shears to obtain the cobweb itself. 

You can find large amounts of cobwebs in abandoned mineshafts, particularly around cave spider spawners.}}

{{BlockSprite|end-stone}} '''End Stone'''
{{Collapse|content=End stone is a block that generates exclusively in the End. Aside from generated structures, it makes up the entirety of solid ground existing in the End. 

With a blast resistance of 45, end stone cannot be picked up by endermen nor can it be destroyed by the ender dragon. This makes it a useful defensive block both inside and outside of the End!

But don‚Äôt forget to grab some before you leave! As it is the only block that you can place chorus fruit on, you will need to take some home with you if you want to grow any chorus plants!

End stone can be mined with a pickaxe of any level.}}
{{BlockSprite|sand}} '''Sand'''
{{Collapse|content=Sand generates naturally in many Overworld biomes, but it will always be found in deserts, beaches, and rivers. Red sand generates in badlands biomes and its variants. It is also almost always used to cover up buried treasure chests!

Since a shovel is the fastest method of breaking and obtaining sand, make sure to keep a shovel handy if you‚Äôre on a treasure hunt!

While sand generally appears in layers that are four blocks deep, supported by stone or sandstone, sand can also spawn floating in the air.

Be careful! As sand is affected by gravity, if you place or break a block near this precariously perched pile of sand, the entire cluster will come crashing down!

Sand that falls on a mob or player will cause them to suffocate. But sand that falls on non-solid blocks, such as tour he‚Äôs, redstone dust, rails, or slabs, will break and drop a block of sand instead of piling up. 

Sand can be used to craft a number of decorative blocks, and it is also one of the two main ingredients required to craft TNT. When smelted, it will produce glass.}}
{{BlockSprite|soul-sand}} '''Soul Sand'''
{{Collapse|content=Covered in tiny screaming faces, soul sand is found below Y level 65 in the Nether or in the nether wart room of nether fortresses. It is used for growing nether wart, but four pieces of soul sand are also required to construct a wither!

Soul Sand will slow the movement of any player or mob that walks over it. If it is placed above ice, packed ice, or slime blocks, the slowing effect will be even stronger!

When it is placed underwater, it will also release a column of bubbles that will speedily lift any players, mobs, and items up to the surface!}} 

{{BlockSprite|stone}} '''Stone'''
{{Collapse|content=One of the earliest blocks added to the game, stone is an extremely common block that is found in the Overworld. It will drop nothing unless mined with a pickaxe, in which case it will drop cobblestone.

Cobblestone can be smelted in a furnace to transform it back into stone. Stone will also be created if lava comes in contact with flowing water.

Stone is everywhere! So much so that it almost had a place in the very name of the game! Before Minecraft was known as ‚ÄúMinecraft‚Äù, the game was nearly called ‚ÄúMinecraft: Order of the Stone‚Äù!}}
{{BlockSprite|diamond-ore}} '''Diamonds''' 
{{Collapse|content=DIAMONDS! There are few other blocks with such excitement upon their discovery. Generating naturally in the world below Y level 16, diamond ore will drop diamonds when mined with an iron or diamond pickaxe.

Used to craft the best tools and armour in the game, every player hopes to find diamonds while mining. However, be careful while collecting them! The last thing you want is for your diamonds to fall into a patch of hidden lava!}}
{{BlockSprite|emerald-ore}} '''Emerald Ore'''{{Collapse|content=Emerald ore is one of the rarest mineral blocks in the game! Generating between Y levels 4 and 32 in mountain biomes, emerald ore will drop emeralds when mined with an iron or diamond pickaxe.

These emeralds can be used as currency in villager trades, or to power beacons.}}

{{BlockSprite|gold-ore}} '''Gold Ore'''{{Collapse|content=Mined with an iron or diamond pickaxe, gold ore is a rare mineral block that can be found below Y level 32 in the majority of biomes. In badlands biomes and its variants, gold ore generated between Y levels 32 and 79.}}

{{BlockSprite|iron-ore}} '''Iron Ore'''
{{Collapse|content=Generating between Y levels 1 and 63, iron is the most common mineral block that can be used to craft armour and tools! Arguably the next best alternative to diamond, you need at least a stone pickaxe in order to mine it.

As it does not generate above Y level 63, you will not be able to find iron ore in the upper levels of mountain biomes.

Iron ore is only useful once it is smelted into iron ingots, which can be crafted into better armour, tools, and weapons!

Of course, you can also craft yourself a handy bucket or a pair of shears.}}
{{BlockSprite|lapis-lazuli-ore}} '''Lapis Lazuli Ore'''
{{Collapse|content=Generating below Y levels 31, with the highest concentrations found between Y levels 13 and 16, lapis lazuli ore drops lapis lazuli when mined with a stone pickaxe or better. 

Previously used as a dye, lapis lazuli can also be used to enchant items in an enchantment table. Depending on the enchantment level, 1-3 pieces of lapis lazuli will be consumed per enchantment.}}
{{BlockSprite|redstone-ore}} '''Redstone Ore'''
{{Collapse|content=Generating below Y levels 16, redstone ore will drop 4-5 pieces of redstone dust when mined with an iron pickaxe. Redstone ore will emit light and red particles when it is clicked, updated, or contacted by any mob or player.

Redstone dust is used for brewing and crafting but its primary use is to transmit power via redstone circuitry and wires.}}
{{BlockSprite|nether-quartz-ore}} '''NetherQuartz Ore'''
{{Collapse|content=Nether quartz ore is the only ore that generates in the Nether, which is also the only source of nether quartz. Generating between Y levels 7 and 117, nether quartz ore will drop one piece of nether quartz as long as it is mined with a pickaxe.

Four pieces of nether quartz can be crafted into its block form.}}
{{BlockSprite|purpur-block}} '''Purpur'''
{{Collapse|content=Purpur blocks and purpur pillars are decorative blocks that are naturally generated in end city dungeons and end ship structures which appear on and near the outer islands in the End.

Alternatively, purpur blocks can be crafted from four pieces of popped chorus fruit, and, if you make these blocks into slabs, you can use these slabs to craft some fancy purpur pillars!}}
{{BlockSprite|end-stone-bricks}} '''End Stone Bricks'''{{Collapse|content=End stone bricks can be crafted from four pieces of end stone. As with other brick blocks, it can be mined with any pickaxe, but will drop nothing if broken without a pickaxe.

End stone bricks can also be obtained by disassembling the structures in end cities, which are generated on the outed islands of the End.}}

{{BlockSprite|fire}} '''Fire'''
{{Collapse|content=Fire is a harmful non-solid block that will spread to nearby flammable blocks unless fire spread has been turned off with the command /gamerule doFireTick false. Blocks and item that catch fire will burn for some time before being destroyed.

Even with fire spread enabled, all is not lost! Fires eventually burn out on their own. However, fires started on netherrack or magma blocks will burn forever, and will need to be put out manually.

Coming in contact with fire will set you on fire. You can either wait for it to burn out, or you can jump in water to extinguish the fire before it does too much damage!

Tired of waiting for lava, lightning, blazes, and ghosts to start fires for you? You can light your very own fires with a flint and steel or fire charge! Remember, with great power comes great responsibility!}}
{{BlockSprite|lava}} '''Lava'''
{{Collapse|content=Ouch! That‚Äôs some Hot Stuff! Spawning in pools in the Overworld and covering most of the Nether, lava is a light-emitting fluid block that causes fire damage.

When combined with water, lava can produce stone, cobblestone, or obsidian depending on how the two fluids interact.

When gathered in a bucket, lava can be used as fuel. It has the longest burning value in the game, capable of smelting 100 items with a single bucket of lava!

Items that fall into lava will be destroyed, so hold on to your diamonds and be careful while mining! Yet another reason not to dig down!}}
{{BlockSprite|magma-block}} '''Magma Block'''
{{Collapse|content=Magma blocks are light-emitting blocks that can be found in the Nether between Y levels 23 and 37. It can also be found in the Overworld at the bottom of ocean ravines, in underwater caverns, and in some underwater ruins.

Alternatively, a magma blocks can be crafted from four magma cream. While magma blocks do not destroy items, they will hurt mobs and players that stand on top of them.

Players can avoid taking fire damage from magma blocks by using fire resistance potions, wearing Frost Walker boots, or simply sneaking while walking across them.

Underwater magma blocks create whirlpool bubble columns that drag any items, boats, mobs, or players caught in them at the bottom of the sea. Luckily, you can restore your air by swimming through a magma block‚Äôs bubble column.

But be careful! Despite being underwater, magma blocks will still hurt you if you come in contact with them.}}
{{BlockSprite|glowstone}} '''Glowstone''' 
{{Collapse|content=Glowstone is a light-emitting block that occurs naturally in the Nether. It generates in clusters that hang from the underside of netherrack.

Unless it is mined with Silk Touch, glowstone will shatter into 2-4 pieces of glowstone dust. If it is broken with a Fortune tool, it has a higher chance to drop more glowstone dust, but it will never drop more than four pieces of dust.

You can craft four pieces of glowstone dust back together to form one piece of glowstone.

With a light level of 15, glowstone produces the brightest possible light level in the game. Use it to light up your creations, or craft it into a redstone lamp for a more decorative alternative.}}
{{BlockSprite|gravel}} '''Gravel'''
{{Collapse|content=Gravel is affected by gravity! If there is no block beneath it when mined, it will fall until it lands on the next available block. However if it falls on non-solid blocks (such as torches, redstone, rails, or slabs,)

or on soul sand, it will break and drop a piece of gravel instead of piling up. 

When broken, there is a 10% chance that a piece of flint will be dropped instead of gravel.

The Fortune enchantment increases the chance of flint dropping to 14% at Fortune I, 25% at Fortune II, and 100% chance at Fortune III.}}
{{BlockSprite|netherrack}} '''Netherrack'''
{{Collapse|content=Netherrack makes up a majority of the Nether‚Äôs terrain. Breaking netherrack by hand will yield nothing, but mining it with any pickaxe will shred through it in a fraction of a second!

Once netherrack has been set on fire, it will burn indefinitely, making it a unique decorative block.

Speaking of decorative blocks, netherrack can be smelted and crafted into nether brick blocks, so you don‚Äôt even need to find a nether fortress if you want some!}}
{{BlockSprite|obsidian}} '''Obsidian''' 
{{Collapse|content=Anyone interested in taking the Ice Bucket Challenge? Running water over lava source blocks will create obsidian, but it will require a diamond pickaxe to successfully mine it.

With a blast resistance of 6000, obsidian has the highest blast resistance a player can obtain in Survival mode, which explains why it takes so long to mine!

But since it‚Äôs required to build a nether portal or craft a beacon, enchantment table, or ender chest, it‚Äôs definitely worth the wait!}}
{{BlockSprite|prismarine}} '''Prismarine'''

{{Collapse|content=Prismarine is a stone-like decorative block that only appears underwater in ocean monuments. It can be crafted from prismarine shards which are dropped when guardians and elder guardians are killed.}}

{{BlockSprite|water}} '''Water'''
{{Collapse|content=Water water everywhere! Water is a renewable fluid that generated naturally in large quantities to form oceans, lakes, rivers, and springs in the Overworld. In snowy biomes, water can freeze and turn into ice.

Water source blocks can be collected with a bucket. Emptying these buckets of water into a 2x2 space will create an infinite water source! However, water will evaporate when you try to place it in the Nether.

Water will spread downwards endlessly as long as there is available space below it. However, it can only flow 7 blocks horizontally from its source block if it is on a flat surface, washing item along with it.

Item that are dropped in water will eventually float back to the surface. 

To get through water, you will need to swim! Unlike items, you do not float. Underwater, you have 15 seconds before you begin to run out of air, so make sure to remember to swim back to the surface to catch your breath!}}
{{BlockSprite|sea-lantern}} '''Sea Lantern'''
{{Collapse|content=Sea lanterns are underwater light sources that appear in ocean monuments and in underwater ruins. The sea lantern itself can only be mined with a Silk Touch tool. If it is broken by anything else, it will drop 2-3 prismarine crystals instead.

Since it does not drop any prismarine shards when broken, the other material required to craft sea lanterns, this is a very insufficient way to gather sea lanterns.

With a light level of 15, sea lanterns produce the brightest possible light level in the game. However, they can only be used for decoration! Sea lanterns can also be used to activate a conduit by building a structure around it! Decorative and useful!}}
{{BlockSprite|snow-block}} '''Snow'''{{Collapse|content=Snowball fight! Snow generates naturally in snowy biomes and above Y level 95 in mountain biomes. Snow will fall instead of rain in these areas and it will coat the ground in a thin, pristine layer of snow.

It will not melt in these areas sun, however, placing a block with a light level of 12 or more will cause surrounding snow to melt.}}

==== Plants ====
{{BlockSprite|short-grass}} '''Grass'''
{{Collapse|content=Grass is a non-solid block that generates in most biomes with grassy soil. When broken without shears, grass will drop 0-1 wheat seeds.

Tall grass will generate in plains or savannas, and will drop two pieces of grass when broken with shears.}}
{{BlockSprite|rose-bush}} '''Tall Flowers'''{{Collapse|content=There are four variants of tall flowers: sunflowers, lilacs, rose bushes, and peonies. Flowers generate naturally on dirt and grass blocks. While most flowers can be created by using bone meal on grass, tall flowers cannot.

However, if you use bone meal on a tall flower, it will spawn a second tall flower as an item. While they are mainly used for decoration, tall flowers can also be crafted into dye.}}

{{BlockSprite|fern}} '''Ferns'''{{Collapse|content=Ferns are variants of grass that have the same characteristics as grass, but can only be found in jungle, taiga, snowy taiga, and giant tree taiga biomes. When broken without shears, ferns drop 0-1 wheat seeds. 

Excluding jungle biomes, large ferns generate in the same biomes as their shorter counterparts. When a large ferns generate is broken with shears, it will drop two instead of one.}}

{{BlockSprite|dead-bush}} '''Dead Bush'''
{{Collapse|content=Dead bushes generate on sand, red sand, podzol, dirt, coarse dirt, and terracotta in deserts, badlands, and giant tree taiga biomes. They cannot be grown with bonemeal, but they can be collected with shears. 

If they are broken without shears, they drop 0-2 sticks instead of. Ever wanted to add more life and colour into your home? As with flowers and saplings, dead bushes can also be planted in flower pots!}}

{{BlockSprite|cocoa}} '''Cocoa Pod'''
{{Collapse|content=Cocoa pods can be found growing on normal-sized, naturally-generated jungle trees. Jungle trees grown by the player do not spawn cocoa pods. Grown on jungle logs, cocoa pods have three stages of growth.

If a cocoa pod is destroyed before it is fully grown, it will only drop one cocoa bean instead of 2-3 when it is ready to be harvested. The resulting cocoa beans can be crafted into cookies. Yum!}}

{{BlockSprite|chorus-flower}} '''Chorus Flower'''
{{Collapse|content=Chorus flowers are used to grow chorus plants when planted on end stone. They are naturally generated on the outer islands of the End at the top of chorus trees in their purple, fully-grown state.

Until a chorus flower reaches the age of five, it will attempt to grow as long as the block above it is air. A chorus flower can be broken and replanted to reset its age to zero. Make sure you break chorus flowers separately!

If you break the chorus plant or end stone they are attached to, they will break automatically and drop nothing!

Unlike other crops and saplings, bone meal cannot be used to force chorus flowers to grow.}}

{{BlockSprite|chorus-plant}} '''Chorus Plant'''
{{Collapse|content=Chorus plants are naturally generated on the outer islands of the End. They can be grown from chorus flowers. If a chorus plant branches off while it‚Äôs growing, another chorus plant will grow at the top of the growth.

A chorus plant will drop 0-1 chorus fruit when broken. Chorus plants will break automatically if the block supporting it is broken.}}
{{BlockSprite|dead-tube-coral-fan}} '''Dead Coral Fans'''{{Collapse|content=Dead coral fans are the dead variants of coral fans. They are non-solid blocks that come in 5 variants: tube, brain, bubble fire, and horn. Coral fans die after a few seconds if they are not placed in water.

Dead coral fans are grey and cannot be brought back to life.}}{{BlockSprite|red-mushroom}} '''Mushrooms'''
{{Collapse|content=Mushrooms are fungi that naturally grow and spread in dark areas with a light level of 12 or less. They also generate in the Nether and mushroom field biomes. If you shear a mooshroom, it will drop 5 mushrooms and turn into a normal cow. 

When bone meal is used on a mushroom, there is a chance that it can grow into a huge mushroom! Planning on making your own mushroom farm so you can make even more delicious stew?

Mushrooms can only be planted in light levels of 13 or less, but directly under the sky unless they are planted on mycelium or podzol. 

If the conditions are right, mushrooms will spread randomly onto nearby blocks, but they will only spread if there are fewer than 5 mushrooms of the same type in a 9x9x3 area.}}
{{BlockSprite|oak-leaves}} '''Leaves'''
{{Collapse|content=Leaves grow as part of trees. Their appearance varies depending on the type of tree they are grown from and the biome they are currently in. When a tree is chopped down, its leaves will spontaneously decay and disappear.

Even if leaves are connected to a log, if they are more than 6 blocks away, they will begin to decay.

Leaves have a 5% chance of dropping saplings. Jungle leaves have an even lower chance of dropping saplings, with a drop rate of only 2.5%! On top of saplings, oak and dark oak trees have a 0.5% chance of dropping an apple. 

Leaves can be collected with shears or a Silk Touch tool. Player-placed leaves will not experience decay.
Depending on whether you have your graphics set to ‚ÄòFast‚Äô or ‚ÄòFancy‚Äô, leaves will appear solid or transparent!}}
{{BlockSprite|lily-pad}} '''Lily Pad'''{{Collapse|content=Lily pads are flat blocks that can be found growing on water in swamps or in the wheat farm rooms of woodland mansions. They can also be obtained while fishing.

You can stand on, walk, and jump across the tops of lily pads and they will not break. However, they will break and drop as an entity if you hit them with a boat or punch them.}}{{BlockSprite|melon}} '''Melon'''{{Collapse|content=Melon are blocks that are naturally generated in jungle biomes and in the stem farm rooms of woodland mansions. When broken they will drop 3-7 tasty melon slices. Melon slices can be crafted back into a melon block.

As it takes nine melon slices to reassemble a melon block, this is an inefficient storage method!}}{{BlockSprite|melon-stem}} '''Melon Stem'''
{{Collapse|content=A melon stem is grown from melon seeds when they are planted on farmland. When the melon stem is fully grown, melons can grow on any adjacent dirt, grass, or farmland block.

While the stem‚Äôs seven stages of growth can be accelerated by bone meal, bone meal cannot be used to speed up the growth of an actual melon.

A single stem can grow an unleaded number of melons, so don‚Äôt break it! When a melon stem is broken, it will drop 0-3 melon seeds.}}
{{BlockSprite|red-mushroom-block}} '''Mushroom Blocks'''{{Collapse|content=Mushroom are solid blocks that make up huge mushrooms. They come in three varieties: red mushroom, brown mushroom and mushroom stem. You can obtain a mushroom block by breaking it with a Silk Touch tool.

When broken with any other tool or by hand mushroom blocks will occasionally drop their respective mushroom types.}}{{BlockSprite|nether-wart}} '''Nether Wart'''
{{Collapse|content=Nether wart can be found growing in nether fortresses. It grows on soul sand, and breaking a fully grown nether wart will drop 2-4 nether wart. An immature nether wart plant will drop a single nether wart. Interested in more nether wart?

Fortune tools will increase the maximum number of nether wart dropped by 1 per level! Nether wart‚Äôs primary purpose is to brew awkward potions, but it can also be crafted into a nether wart block or red nether bricks!}}
{{BlockSprite|potatoes}} '''Potatoes'''
{{Collapse|content=Potayto, potahto! Potatoes are food items that can be planted, eaten raw, or cooked into baked potatoes. One potato restores 1 hunger and 0.6 hunger saturation, while a baked potato will restore 5 hunger and 6 hunger saturation.

A fully grown potato crop drops 1 to 4 potatoes and have 2% chance of dropping an additional poisonous potato. You can find potatoes generating naturally in the farm plots of villages, as rare loot from zombies, and in shipwreck supply chests.

Pigs love potatoes! They will breed if they are given potatoes. Villagers will also become willing if they pick up 12 potatoes.}}{{BlockSprite|tube coral fan}} '''Coral Fans'''

{{Collapse|content=Coral fans are non-solid blocks that come in 5 variants: tube, brain, bubble, fire, and horn. They come in their respective colours of blue, pink, purple, red, and yellow. Coral fans generate naturally in the coral reef structures of warm oceans.

They can be placed on all sides of a bock except for the bottom. Coral fans will break and drop nothing unless they are mined with a Silk Touch tool.}}

{{BlockSprite|dead tube coral block}} '''Dead Coral Block'''

{{Collapse|content=Dead coral fans are the dead variants of coral. They are solid blocks that come in 5 variants: tube, brain, bubble, fire, and horn. Coral blocks die after a few seconds if they are not placed in water.

Dead coral blocks are grey and cannot be brought back to life.}}

{{BlockSprite|tube coral block}} '''Coral Blocks'''
{{Collapse|content=Coral blocks are solid blocks that come in 5 variants: tube, brain, bubble, fire, and horn. They come in respective colours of blue, pink, purple, red, and yellow. Coral blocks will break and drop nothing unless they are mined with a Silk Touch tool.

Coral blocks generate naturally un the coral structures of warm oceans. It requires water on at least one of its sides to stay alive.}}{{BlockSprite|kelp}} '''Kelp'''
{{Collapse|content=Kelp is an animated underwater plant that generates in all ocean biomes, excluding frozen and warm oceans. While it can be planted on a variety of blocks, it will only grow if it is planted underwater with water above it.

Breaking part of a kelp stalk will cause all the kelp above it to break off as well, and each piece of kelp has a random chance to drop a kelp item. If you smelt kelp in a furnace, it becomes dried kelp, which is edible!}}
{{BlockSprite|tube-coral}} '''Corals'''
{{Collapse|content=Corals are non-solid blocks that come in 5 variants: tube, brain, bubble, fire, and horn. They come in their respective colours of blue, pink, purple, red, and yellow. Coral generates naturally in the coral reef structures of warm oceans.

Coral will break and drop nothing unless it is mined with a Silk Touch tool. If you are in a warm ocean biomes, coral can be grown by using bone meal on underwater dirt, course dirt, sand, red sand, or gravel.

It requires water on at least one of its sides to stay alive.}}{{BlockSprite|carrots}} '''Carrots'''
{{Collapse|content=Crunch crunch crunch! These little crops can be enjoyed on their own, no cooking required! One carrot will restore 3 hunger and provide 3.6 hunger saturation. Alternatively, you can stick them straight back into the ground to get even more carrots!

You can find them generating naturally in the farm plots of villages, as rare loot from zombies, and in shipwreck supply chests.

Carrots are the favorurite food of pigs and rabbits, which will breed if they are given carrots. Villagers will also become willing to have children if they pick up 12 carrots.

Feeling fancy? Covering a carrot in gold nuggets will create a golden carrot - an important ingredient in night vision potions!}}
{{BlockSprite|cactus}} '''Cactus'''
{{Collapse|content=Ouch! Be careful so that you don‚Äôt get pricked to death! Found naturally in desert and badlands biomes, cacti will grow to a height of three blocks. Cactus must be planted on sand with space on all four adjacent sides.

If the area where a cactus has been planted becomes unsuitable, such as when a solid block is placed next to it or it‚Äôs supporting block is removed, the cactus will break and drop as an item.

Smelting cactus in a furnace will give you green dye. Aside from hurting when you bump into it, cactus will also destroy any items that contact it.}}
{{BlockSprite|beetroots}} '''Beetroot Seeds'''
{{Collapse|content=Beetroot seeds can be acquired from end city chests, dungeon chests, chest minecarts in abandoned mineshafts, and in woodland mansion chests. Village farm plots have a 10% chance of being beetroot.

When placed on farmland, beetroot seeds will undergo four states of growth before they are ready to be harvested. When they are fully grown, they can be broken to produce beetroots and 0-3 beetroot seeds.

Beetroot seeds share the same uses as other seeds, such as breeding chickens and taming parrots.}}
{{BlockSprite|pumpkin}} '''Pumpkin'''{{Collapse|content=Pumpkins are blocks that spawn in random clusters on grass blocks in most Overworld biomes. You can also find them growing in the stem farm rooms of woodland mansions. They can be crafted into pumpkin seeds or carved.

While the fastest way to harvest a pumpkin is with an axe, they can be successfully harvested with anything. One of the main ingredients in pumpkin pie, when carved, pumpkins can also be used to construct snow golems and iron golems!}}{{BlockSprite|pumpkin-stem}} '''Pumpkin Seeds'''
{{Collapse|content=Pumpkin seeds are used to grow pumpkin stems. When planted on farmland, they will undergo seven stages of growth. There are a number of different ways to obtain pumpkin seeds!

They can be found in dungeon chests, chest minecarts in abandoned mineshafts, and in woodland mansion chests. Crafting pumpkins or shearing an uncarved pumpkin will yield 4 pumpkin seeds.

Destroying pumpkin seeds will drop 0-3 seeds. Other that being used for farming, wheat seeds share the same uses as other seeds, such as breeding chickens and taming parrots.}}{{BlockSprite|oak-sapling}} '''Sapling'''{{Collapse|content=After chopping down half the forest, it may be a good idea to replant! A sapling is a non-solid block that can be grown into a tree. Saplings come in six varieties: oak, birch, spruce, jungle, acacia and dark oak.

When broken leaves have a 5% chance of dropping saplings. Jungle leaves have an even lower chance of dropping sapling with a drop rate of only 2.5%!}}{{BlockSprite|seagrass}} '''Seagrass'''
{{Collapse|content=Seagrass is a non-solid animated plant block that generates in all oceans, excluding frozen oceans. It will drop nothing unless it is harvested using shears. Seagrass can be used to breed turtles!

Using seagrass on a baby turtle will also speed up its growing time. Can‚Äôt find seagrass for whatever reason? Turtles will drop 0-2 seagrass when killed. But leave the turtles alone!

Using bone meal underwater is a much friendlier way of generating seagrass!}}
{{BlockSprite|sugar-cane}} '''Sugar Cane'''{{Collapse|content=Sugar cane is a block that grows next to water in the Overworld. While it grows next to a max height of 3, there is a rare chance a fourth block will generate on top of the ones that have already been generated.

It can be crafted into paper or sugar. If any of its supporting blocks are removed, all unsupported sugar cane blocks will uproot and drop as items.}}{{BlockSprite|ice}} '''Ice'''
{{Collapse|content=Watch your step! Ice is slippery, and will cause mobs, items, and players to slide across it. This can be used to your advantage though! If you run and jump while on ice, you will travel faster than if you were to do the same on any other block type!

This translucent block is generated in snowy biomes, where it is cold enough to freeze into ice. Excluding sunlight, ice will revert to water if exposed to a light level greater than 11.

It cannot be gathered unless it is mined with a Silk Touch pickaxe. Breaking it with anything will leave a source block of water in its place.}}
{{BlockSprite|vines}} '''Vines'''{{Collapse|content=Vines are non-solid blocks that naturally generated in jungles and swamps. Vines will spread downward and to adjacent blocks over time. They can be broken with anything, but they can only be collected with shears.

Running through vines will slow your movement speed, but can also be used to negate fall damage if you pass through them. As you can climb up and down them, vines are living ladders!}}{{BlockSprite|wheat}} '''Wheat Seeds'''{{Collapse|content=Wheat seeds are acquired by breaking all variants of grass. When they are planted on farmland, they will undergo eight stages of growth. Harvesting a fully-grown wheat crop will yield 0-3 seeds and one wheat.

If they are harvested early, they will only drop one wheat seed. Village farm plots have a 50% chance of being wheat crops.

Other than being used for farming wheat seeds share the same uses as other seeds, such as breeding chickens and taming parrots.}}

==== Mechanisms ====
{{BlockSprite|dropper}} '''Dropper'''{{Collapse|content=A dropper is a block that can be used to eject items or push items into another container. Crafted from cobblestone and redstone, it has 9 slots of inventory space.

It can be placed so that its output faces any direction, but it will face towards the player when placed.}}{{BlockSprite|chest}} '''Chest'''{{Collapse|content=My inventory is full! Thankfully, there‚Äôs a chest for that! Crafted from eight planks, a chest has 27 storage slots. It can be placed next to another chest to create a double chest, which has 54 storage slots.

If a chest is broken, it will drop all of its contents. Chests, containing a variety of items, are naturally generated in dungeons, strongholds, temples, nether fortresses, villages, end cities, shipwrecks, and more! Lots of loot!}}{{BlockSprite|oak-trapdoor}} '''Trapdoors'''{{Collapse|content=Trapdoors are solid, partly transparent blocks that can be used as openable barriers. There are seven different trapdoor types: oak wood, spruce wood, birch wood, jungle wood, acacia wood, dark oak wood, and iron.

Each trapdoor type has a different design. Trapdoors can be placed on the top or bottom of blocks, and the way they open will depend on where their hinges are placed. When open, trapdoors can be climbed on just like a ladder.}}{{BlockSprite|tnt}} '''TNT'''
{{Collapse|content=Creepers not causing enough explosions in your life? Crafted from four sand and five gunpowder, TNT is a block that can be used to initiate an explosion! But be careful - there are many ways to trigger TNT!

Powdered redstone currents, being hit by a flaming arrow, and other explosions are only a few of the ways TNT will be ignited. While TNT can be broken instantly by hand or tool, primed TNT cannot be broken, so make sure you‚Äôre out of the blast zone!

TNT can b found as loot in shipwreck supply chests and in buried treasure chests. TNT traps can also be found, or triggered, in desert temples and woodland mansions. Boom!}}
{{BlockSprite|redstone-torch}} '''Redstone Torch'''{{Collapse|content=A redstone torch is a non-solid block that can be used as a toggleable redstone power source, as well as a signal inverter. They can be used as crafting ingredients or as components in redstone contraptions.

A redstone torch will remain active unless the block it is attached to is powered. Effectively, a redstone torch will invert the signal applied to its attachment block.}}{{BlockSprite|rail}} '''Rails'''
{{Collapse|content=Travelling in style! Sixteen rails can be crafted from six iron and a stick. When you string them together, you create a path that your Minecart can travel over!

Rails can be found naturally generated in woodland mansions and along the floors of abandoned mineshafts!

They can be successfully mined by anything, but a pickaxe is the fastest.

Achievement hunting? If you travel by minecart to a point at least 500m in a single direction of where you started, you will unlock the ‚ÄúOn A Rail‚Äù achievement!}}{{BlockSprite|block-of-redstone}} '''Redstone Block'''
{{Collapse|content=A block of redstone is a decorative and functional mineral block, which acts as a redstone power source that cannot be turned off. It powers redstone dust, comparators, and repeaters to power level 15. It also activates any mechanism components.

A block of redstone can be crafted from 9 redstone dust. As redstone blocks can be crafted back into dust, redstone blocks are also a compact way to store redstone dust! Unlike redstone ore, which requires an iron pickaxe to mine,

a block of redstone can be mined with any pickaxe. If it is mined without a pickaxe, it will drop nothing.}}
{{BlockSprite|stone-button}} '''Buttons'''

{{Collapse|content=A button is a non-solid block that can provide temporary redstone power. Buttons come in wood and stone. The wood buttons come in each of the wood types. Whenever it is activated, a wood buttons come in will remain active for 15 redstone ticks,

or roughly 1.5 seconds. In comparison, a stone button will remain active for 10 redstone ticks, or roughly 1 second.}}{{BlockSprite|command-block-side}} '''Command Block'''{{Collapse|content=A command block is a block that executes commands. Due to how easy it can be misused, it can only be obtained through cheats! Command blocks are frequently used on servers and in custom maps.

As command blocks are granted all permissions, some chat commands have been disabled and cannot be run in command blocks. Some of these include: /ban, /deop, /kick, /op, and /whitelist.}}{{BlockSprite|daylight-detector}} '''Detector'''{{Collapse|content=Crafted from wood slabs, glass, and nether quartz, a daylight detector is a block that outputs a redstone signal depending on sky light levels. A daylight detector will activate when exposed to sufficient daylight. Daylight detectors can also be inverted.

An inverted daylight detector will activate when exposure to daylight is low enough. Sources of light, such as torches and glowstone, will not activate a daylight detector.}}{{BlockSprite|dispenser}} '''Dispenser'''{{Collapse|content=A dispenser is a solid block used as a redstone component to dispense items. It can be crafted from cobblestone, redstone dust, and a bow in the crafting recipe!

Dispensers are naturally generated in jungle temples. A dispenser has 9 inventory slots. Dispensers interact differently with various item types. Buckets will collect and place fluids! Throwable items will be thrown!

Arrows will be fired! Blocks will be placed! The list goes on!}}{{BlockSprite|oak-door}} '''Door'''{{Collapse|content=Knock knock! Who‚Äôs there? A door is a block that can be used as a switchable barrier. Wood doors can be crafted from each of the different wood types.

They can be opened and closed by players and villagers, and they can be broken down by zombies if you are playing on the Hard difficulty. Iron doors can only be opened with redstone power.}}{{BlockSprite|oak-fence-gate}} '''Fence Gate'''{{Collapse|content=Having difficulties climbing in and out of the enclosure you made for your farm animals? Time to make yourself a fence gate! A fence gate is a block that functions both as a door and as a fence.

They can be attached to fences as well as walls and other blocks. Fence gates can be crafted in each of the different wood types. They can be opened by hand or with redstone power?}}

{{BlockSprite|hopper}} '''Hopper'''
{{Collapse|content=A hopper is a block that can be used to catch item entities, or transfer items into and out of containers. Crafted from five iron and a chest, a hopper has 5 inventory slots. The ‚Äúoutput‚Äù tube of a hopper can be oriented depending on where you want your

items to go. Don‚Äôt feel like waiting around for your furnace to smelt your ores? Hook up a few hoppers to your furnace, attach them to chests, and you‚Äôll have a simple, automated setup!}}{{BlockSprite|Lever}} '''Lever'''{{Collapse
|content=
Puuuullll the lever! A lever is a non-solid block that can provide switchable redstone power. It has an 'on' state and an 'off' state depending on its placement.

When placed on the side of blocks, down is 'on' and up is 'off'. When placed on the top or bottom of blocks, 'on' is north or west and 'off' is south or east. Too much to remember? Just flick it on and off a few times!

Just make sure you don't pull the wrong lever!
}}{{BlockSprite|note-block}} '''Note Block'''
{{Collapse|content=A note block is a musical block that emits sound. Crafted from eight planks and a piece of redstone dust, note blocks play a sound and release a coloured music note when they are hit or powered by redstone.

You can change the note pitch by a semitone, with a total of two full octaves available to play. The instrument played depends on the material the note block is placed on.

Whether you decide to hook up your note blocks to some redstone or punch as fast as you can, get out there and make some beautiful music!}}
{{BlockSprite|observer}} '''Observer'''{{Collapse|content=I think someone‚Äôs watching me... Oh, it‚Äôs jut an observer! Crafted from cobblestone, redstone, and nether quartz, an observer is a block that emits a redstone signal when an adjacent block is updated.

Observers require a pickaxe to be successfully mined.}}{{BlockSprite|piston}} '''Piston'''{{Collapse|content=A piston is a block capable of pushing movable blocks when activated by redstone. If slime is added to a piston, you will get a sticky piston, which can both push and pull moveable objects when activated with redstone!

Three sticky pistons can be found naturally generated as a part of jungle temples!}}{{BlockSprite|stone-pressure-plate}} '''Pressure Plates'''
{{Collapse|content=A pressure plate is a block that can be used to detect players, mobs, items, and entities. When activated, it will send out a redstone signal. It has four variants, which have different uses depending on the material.

The wooden pressure plate can detect all entities and gives out a maximum signal strength. The stone pressure plate also gives off a maximum signal strength, but it can only detect players and mobs.

Light weighted pressure plates, crafted from gold, can detect all entities, but the signal increases as more entities are added. Finally, the heavy weighted pressure plate, crafted from iron, is similar to the light weighted pressure plate, but it

detects entities in groups of ten.}}
{{BlockSprite|redstone-dust-cross-off}} '''Redstone Dust'''
{{Collapse|content=That‚Äôs quite the contraption you have there! Redstone dust is a mineral that is primarily used to transmit power via redstone circuitry and wires. Aside from redstone circuits, redstone dust is used for brewing and crafting.

When it is placed in the world, redstone dust becomes a ‚Äúredstone wire‚Äù which can transmit power between various points and redstone components. A single piece of redstone dust placed on the ground will appear as a dot.

Redstone dust can be obtained by mining redstone ore. A single redstone ore will drop 4-5 pieces of redstone dust when mined with an iron or diamond pickaxe. Redstone dust can also be acquired by breaking traps, killing witches, looting chests, and trading

with villagers!}}
{{BlockSprite|redstone-comparator-off}} '''Comparator'''{{Collapse|content=A redstone comparator is a block in redstone circuits to maintain, compare, or subtract signal strength, or to measure certain block states. It is crafted from redstone torches, nether quartz, and stone.}}{{BlockSprite|redstone-repeater-off}} '''Repeater'''
{{Collapse|content=A redstone repeater is a block used in redstone circuits to ‚Äúrepeat‚Äù redstone signals back to full strength, delay signals prevent signals moving backwards, or to ‚Äúlock‚Äù signals in one state.

It is crafted from redstone torches, redstone, and stone. A single redstone repeater can be found generated in the hidden room of a jungle temple!}}
{{BlockSprite|redstone-lamp}} '''Redstone Lamp'''

{{Collapse|content=A redstone lamp is a block which emits light when activated with a redstone signal. Crafted with redstone and glowstone, redstone lamps produce a light level of 15.

Inactive redstone lamps do not produce any light. Even though glowstone will shatter into dust when mined without Silk Touch, redstone lamps can be successfully mined with anything!}}

==== Utility Blocks ====
{{BlockSprite|crafting-table}} '''Crafting Table'''
{{Collapse|content=The crafting table. Where would we be without it? In a corner punching stone with our fists and not getting very far, that‚Äôs for sure! After all, what would Minecraft be without crafting?

The crafting table‚Äôs crafting grid is 3x3 and opens up a world of possibilities in comparison to the 2x2 crafting grid in your inventory! Combining four planks creates a crafting table.

Crafting tables also generate naturally in some structures such as village libraries, witch huts, and igloos. Not sure how to craft a certain item? You can access the recipe book to the left of the crafting grid,

which stores recipes for reference and one-click crafting!}}
{{BlockSprite|enchanting-table}} '''Enchantment''' 
{{Collapse|content=Hoarding levels is nice, but do you know what is even nicer? Using those levels to enchant all of you gear! The enchantment table allows players to spend their experience levels to enchant tools, books, and armour.

Despite being created from diamonds and obsidian, it can be mined with a pickaxe of any level. If it‚Äôs mined without a pickaxe, it will be destroyed. In order to have access to the maximum enchantment level of 30,

fifteen bookshelves must be placed around the enchantment table. Lapis lazuli is also used in the enchantment process. Depending on the enchantment level, 1-3 pieces of lapis lazuli will be consumed per enchantment.

The arcane glyphs that float from nearby bookshelves to the enchantment table as well as cryptic glyphs in the enchanting table‚Äôs interface are from the Standard Galactic Alphabet,

a simple alphabet substitution cipher that was used in the Commander Keen computer game series.}}{{BlockSprite|ender-chest}} '''Ender Chest'''
{{Collapse|content=Great for stashing your valuables for safekeeping, the inventory of an ender chest is unique to every player! An ender chest is crafted from eight obsidian and an eye of ender. Emitting a light level of 7,  an ender chest has 27

inventory slots for storage, and can be placed next to other ender chests without joining. All ender chests share the same inventory, so you can easily transport materials between locations in the world.

They even work between dimensions! Be careful though, if you break an ender chest with anything but a silk touch, it will be destroyed and drop eight obsidian. However, unlike chests, if an ender chest is broken, it will not drop the items held inside.

But don‚Äôt fret! Simply replace another ender chest and you will be able to retrieve your valuables!}}{{BlockSprite|farmland-wet}} '''Farmland'''
{{Collapse|content=Grab your diamond hoe and get farming! Okay, so you don‚Äôt need a diamond hoe to farm, but you‚Äôd sure look fancy! Farmland is required to plant and grow various crops. When you use a hoe on dirt or grass, dry farmland is created.

It will become hydrated of there is water up to four blocks away horizontally or diagonally. The water must be on the same level or one block above the farmland. Rain will also wet farmland. Crops will grow faster on hydrated farmland.

Farmland will dry up and revert to dirt if it does not have a water source and there is no crop planted. But watch where you step! Regardless of its hydration, farmland will turn to dirt if a player or mob jumps or falls on it.

Even if it is mined with a Silk Touch tool, farmland drops dirt.}}
{{BlockSprite|conduit}} '''Conduit'''
{{Collapse|content=A conduit is a beacon-like block that provides Conduit Power and attacks hostile mobs underwater within a spherical range of 32-96 blocks. A conduit is crafted from eight nautilus shells and a heart of the sea.

To activate a conduit, it needs to be placed in the center of a 3x3x3 area of water, which is then enclosed in an activation frame built from prismarine, dark prismarine, prismarine bricks, and sea lanterns.

Conduit Power stops the player breath meter from decreasing, gives underwater night vision, and increases underwater mining speed. Conduits also emit a light level of 15, the brightest level in the game, whether it is activated or not.}}{{BlockSprite|anvil}} '''Anvil'''
{{Collapse|content=Crafted from a total of 31 iron ingots, anvils are quite the investment of resources! However, as they allow players to repair items, rename items, and combine enchantments by using experiments levels, the investment is worth it!

However, be sure to use a pickaxe when mining it. If is is mined without a pickaxe, it will drop nothing! If for whatever reason, you find yourself below an anvil, be careful! Anvils are affected by gravity and will fall, dealing damage based on the

distance they travel. Ouch!}}{{BlockSprite|furnace}} '''Furnace'''

{{Collapse|content=A furnace is a block that is used to smelt blocks and items when provided with fuel. Useful for cooking food and smelting ore, it is crafted from eight cobblestone.

Coal, charcoal, and most wood products can all be used as fuel, but keep in mind that some are better than others!}}{{BlockSprite|beacon}} '''Beacon'''
{{Collapse|content=Despite being crafted from glass, obsidian, and a nether star, beacons can be mined successfully with anything. Beacons can be powered by blocks of emerald, diamond, iron, ore gold.

When powered, a beacon projects a beam of light into the sky and provides varying status effects to any nearby players. A level one beacon only requires 9 mineral blocks.

However, a level four beacon requires 164 mineral blocks to be placed in a pyramid beneath it. When broken down, that‚Äôs a total of 1476 items! Wow!

One beacon not enough for you? If you widen the base, you can put multiple beacons at the top of the same pyramid to get access to even more status effects!}}{{BlockSprite|jukebox}} '''Note Block'''{{Note|Despite the block being a jukebox, it uses the same book as ‚ÄúNote Block‚Äù}}{{Collapse|content=A note block is a musical block that emits sound. Crafted from eight planks and a piece of redstone dust, note blocks play a sound and release a coloured music note when they are hit or powered by redstone.

You can change the note pitch by a semitone, with a total of two full octaves available to play. The instrument played depends on the material the note block is placed on.

Whether you decide to hook up your note blocks to some redstone or punch as fast as you can, get out there and make some beautiful music!}}{{BlockSprite|white-bed}} '''Bed'''

{{Collapse|content=Zzzzzz... Wait, it‚Äôs morning already?! The night just zipped by! You can sleep in a bed at night or during thunderstorms as long as there are no enemy mobs nearby.

This will immediately set it to morning and clear up any nasty weather in the process! If you are playing multiplayer, all players must sleep in a bed for it to change to morning.

Beds are also used to set your spawn point! If you die, you will respawn at the last bed you slept in. However, if your bed is broken or obstructed, your spawn point will be deleted and set to the default world spawn instead.

Sleep is good for our health! If you‚Äôve forgotten to sleep for three in-game days, you will begin to attract phantoms that will swoop down and attack! All of this information is exhausting.

Craft yourself a bed, dye it your favourite colour and get some rest. Sleep well!}}{{BlockSprite|chest}}'''Chest''' {{Note|This book appears in the ‚ÄúMechanisms‚Äù section, but it is slightly modified.}}{{Collapse|content=My inventory is full! Thankfully, there‚Äôs a chest for that! Crafted from eight planks, a chest has 27 storage slots. It can be placed next to another chest to create a double chest, which has 54 storage slots.

If a chest is broken, it will drop all of its contents. Chests, containing a variety of items, are naturally generated in dungeons, strongholds, temples, nether fortresses, villages, end cities, shipwrecks, and more!

Lots of loot!}}{{BlockSprite|brewing-stand}} '''Brewing Stand'''
{{Collapse|content=Bubble and boil! Crafted from a blaze rod and three cobblestone, a brewing stand is used to brew potions, splash potions, and lingering potions. It can brew 1-3 potions at once.

Brewing stands require blaze powder as fuel. A single piece of blaze powder is capable of brewing 20 batches of potions. It will break and drop nothing if it is not mined with anything other than a pickaxe.

Brewing stands will generate naturally in end ships as well as in the basement of igloos.}}{{BlockSprite|oak-sign}} '''Sign'''
{{Collapse|content=There are zombies on my lawn! The sign says to keep off the grass! Can‚Äôt they read?!

Probably not.

Able to stand on their own, or be attached to the side of another block, signs are a handy way to label your property, to organize your house, or simply write messages to other players.

Crafting together six planks and a stick will result in three signs.}}
{{BlockSprite|sea-pickle}} '''Sea Pickle'''
{{Collapse|content=Despite its name, this colony of small stationary animals is not edible!

When placed underwater, sea pickles will emit a low levels of light. You can place up to four sea pickles in one place, and the more you have, the more light they will provide!

Each additional sea pickle adds three light levels. They can be placed out of water but they will not give off any light. They generate naturally at the bottom of lukewarm and warm ocean biomes.

If bone meal is used on sea pickles that are placed on living coral blocks, the number of sea pickles will increase before spreading to empty pieces of the coral!

If smelted, it will produce a piece of lime dye.}}{{BlockSprite|shulker-box}} '''Shulker Box'''
{{Collapse|content=Exploring with a full inventory? Sounds like you need a shulker box! Shulker boxes are chest blocks that can store and transport items. Unlike chests, Shulker boxes retain their inventory when broken!

These items can be retrieved when the shulker boxes is replaced. Crafted from two shulker shells and a chest, a shulker box has 27 inventory spaces, the same as a normal chest.

Shulker boxes can also be dyed! So next time you head out for an adventure, make sure to take some shulker boxes with you!}}
{{BlockSprite|skeleton-skull}} '''Mob Heads'''
{{Collapse|content=Mob heads, or mob skulls, are decorative blocks that can be placed in 16 different orientations on top of blocks as well as in four directions on the side of blocks.

There are six types of mob heads: player, zombie, skeleton, wither skeleton, creeper, and dragon. You can wear these mob heads, and wearing the corresponding mob reduces the detection range of skeletons, zombies, and creepers!

However, mobs will drop only their heads a if they die in charged creeper‚Äùs explosions. Player heads and dragon heads cannot be obtained based drops, but you can find naturally generated dragon heads on end ships in the End.

Finally, there is a 2.5% chance that a wither skeleton will drop its head when it dies. You need three wither skeleton skulls to construct and summon a wither!}}
{{BlockSprite|cauldron}} '''Cauldron'''
{{Collapse|content=A cauldron is a block that can hold liquids. It is crafted from seven iron ingots. It also generates naturally in structures, including witch huts, igloos, and woodland mansions.

Liquids can be removed and added to the cauldron with buckets and glass bottles. While it is a nice decorative blocks that can, it has other uses, such as washing dye off of leather armour, shulker boxes, and banners. Magical!}}
{{BlockSprite|sponge}} '''Sponge'''
