{{Collapse|content=A sponge is a block that can be used to instantly remove water around itself when placed in water. A sponge can absorb up to 65 blocks of water before it becomes a wet sponge! Elder guardians drop a sponge when killed.

As elder guardians do no respawn, sponges are not a renewable material. However ocean monuments also have a chance of generating one or more rooms containing an average of one of more sponges.

But at least your sponges are reusable! You can smelt wet sponges in a furnace to dry them and turn them back into regular√° sponges. Alternatively you can place them in the Nether, where they will also dry out.}}
[[File:Cake side (texture) 10 Years of Minecraft.png]] '''Cake'''{{Collapse
|content=
This cake is not a lie! Unlike other food items in the game, cake cannot be eaten as an item in the hotbar. Before being eaten, it must first be placed on top of another block.

Crafted from milk, wheat, sugar, and an egg, cakes can be time consuming to make. Don't fret! Since a cake has seven slices, you can also take your time eating it!

Each slice of cake restores 2 hunger and provides 0.4 hunger saturation. Eating all seven slices restores 14 hunger and provides a 2.8 hunger saturation!
}}
{{BlockSprite|end rod}} '''End Rod'''
{{Collapse|content=End rods are solid, decorative light sources that emit white particles. They have a light level of 14, equal to that of torches. They generate naturally all over end cities, which are located on the outer islands of the End.

Inside some end city towers, they are placed sideways so that players can use them to parkour to the top. You can collect end rods by any tool or block, or you can craft them by combining popped chorus fruit and blaze rods.}}{{BlockSprite|torch}}'''Torch'''{{Collapse
|content=
Ah, torches. The delightful little light sources that keep enemies at bay and make the inside of your home that much cozier! With a light level of 14, torches prevent enemy mobs from spawning up dark spaces.

Wielding torches in your offhand is an easy way to place them while mining!
}}

==== Manufactured Blocks ====
{{BlockSprite|white-banner}} '''Banners'''
{{Collapse|content=Banners are tall decorative blocks that are highly customizable! They are crafted by combining a stick with six pieces of the same coloured wool. They are crafted colour of the wool used during crafting it will determine the banner‚Äôs base colour

Banners are also generated naturally in some structures, such as outside of end cities and in woodland mansions. Banners can be copied by placing a banner with the same base colour in a crafting grid.

No more toiling away over a crafting table struggling to recreate the same design twice! In Java Edition, you can apply your banner design to a a shield by crafting the two together!}}
{{BlockSprite|block-of-coal}} '''Block of Coal'''
{{Collapse|content=A block of coal is a mineral block that can be used as fuel. It can be crafted from 9 coal. It cannot be crafted from charcoal. If placed, it can be mined with any pickaxe, but it will drop nothing if it is mined without a pickaxe.

A compact way to store your coal, blocks of coal are also an efficient way to use your fuel! One block of coal is able to smelt 80 items. This is ten times longer than a single piece of coal, and, since you used only 9 pieces

to craft a block, it‚Äôs like gaining a free coal! Score!}}
{{BlockSprite|block-of-diamond}} '''Block of Diamond'''
{{Collapse|content=A block of diamond is a decorative and functional mineral block. A compact way to demonstrate your wealth to fellow players, blocks of diamond are crafted from 9 diamonds... As with diamond ore, a block of diamond

can only be mined using an iron or diamond pickaxe. Blocks of diamond can be used to power and increase the effects of a beacon when they are placed in 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, and 9x9 layers in the shape of a pyramid.

That‚Äôs a lot of diamond!}}

{{BlockSprite|block-of-emerald}} '''Block of Emerald'''

{{Collapse|content=A block of emerald is a decorative and functional mineral block. Due to the rare nature of emerald ore, a block of emerald is a compact way to demonstrate the extreme wealth to fellow players! Blocks of emerald are crafted from 9 emeralds.

As with emerald ore, a block of emerald can be used to power and increase the effects of a beacon when they are placed in 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, and 9x9 layers

in the shape of a pyramid. How did you get so many emeralds?!}}

{{BlockSprite|iron-bars}} '''Iron Bars'''

{{Collapse|content=Ever thought glass windows looked too welcoming? Iron bars are blocks that are crafted from six iron ingots. If they are placed without anything on their sides, they will appear as thin vertical columns. However, they will automatically

connect to any blocks or other iron bars placed adjacent to them. Did you know that iron bars placed near a zombie villager in the process of being cured will speed up the healing process? Imprison those zombies!}}{{BlockSprite|block-of-gold}} '''Block of Gold'''
{{Collapse|content=Shiny! Like a treasure from a sunken pirate wreck! A block of gold is a decorative and functional mineral block. You can craft a block of gold from 9 gold ingots, making it a compact way to store your excess gold.

As with gold ore, a block of gold can only be mined using an iron or diamond pickaxe. If you‚Äôre feeling adventurous, fight past the dangers within ocean monuments to get to the central room where 8 blocks of gold are encased in dark prismarine!

Blocks of gold can be used to power and increase the effects of a beacon when they are placed in 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, and 9x9 layers in the shape of a pyramid.}}
{{BlockSprite|block-of-iron}} '''Block of Iron'''
{{Collapse|content=A block of iron is a decorative and functional mineral block. A compact way to store your iron, it can be crafted from 9 iron ingots. As with iron ore, a block of iron can only be mined with a stone pickaxe or better.

Blocks of iron can be used to power and increase the effects of a beacon when they are placed in 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, and 9x9 layers in the pyramid. Blocks of iron are also used in the crafting of anvils, and in the construction of iron golems.}}
{{BlockSprite|block-of-quartz}} '''Blocks of Quartz'''{{Collapse|content=A block of quartz is a purely decorative mineral block. It can be crafted from four pieces of nether quartz. As blocks of nether quartz cannot be crafted back into pieces of nether quartz, blocks of nether quartz are not useful for storage purposes!

These blocks cannot be mined with a pickaxe of any level. However, breaking them without a pickaxe will drop nothing.}}{{BlockSprite|Bookshelf}} '''Bookshelf'''{{Collapse
|content=
Required to obtain higher level enchantments, bookshelves are decorative and functional blocks! Surrounding an enchantment table with bookshelves will increase the enchantment levels you have access to.

In this case, knowledge really is power! Bookshelves generate naturally in villages, strongholds, and woodland mansions. If a bookshelf is broken by anything other than a Silk Touch tool, it will drop three books.
 
These books can be crafted back into a bookshelf by combining them with six wood planks.
}}{{BlockSprite|hay-bale}} '''Hay Bale'''
{{Collapse|content=Hey you! Did you know that falling onto a hay bale reduces your damage by 80%? Now you know! Hay bales can be crafted from nine pieces of wheat. As they can also be crafted back into wheat, this makes hay bales a compact way of storing wheat.

While hay bales are not edible, you can use them to breed llamas and heal horses, donkeys, and mules by up to 10 hearts!}}{{BlockSprite|bricks}} '''Bricks'''

{{Collapse|content=Feel like upgrading the appearance of your house from stone? Bricks are decorative building blocks that can be crafted from four brick items. If they are mined without a pickaxe, they will break and drop nothing.

Bricks have the same blast resistance as other stone-based blocks.}}{{BlockSprite|white-carpet}} '''Carpets'''

{{Collapse|content=Carpets are thin decorative blocks that can be crafted from two pieces of wool. While they are solid and can be stood on, they also allow light to travel through them. Unlike wool, carpets are not destroyed any faster when broken with shears.

Done decorative your house and have carpet left over? Carpet can also be used to give llamas a distinct saddle pattern!}}{{BlockSprite|carved-pumpkin}} '''Carved Pumpkin'''{{Collapse|content=This is Halloween! Pumpkins can be carved by using a pair of shears on them. While carved pumpkins cannot be used to craft any delicious pumpkin pie, they can be used to construct snow golems and iron golems!

When combined with a torch, they become light-emitting jack o‚Äôlanterns. Alternatively, you can toss one on your head! Although you view will be obstructed, you can look directly at endermen without consequence!}}{{BlockSprite|cobblestone-wall}} '''Cobblestone Wall'''
{{Collapse|content=Cobblestone walls are decorative blocks that are centered on top of the blocks they are placed on. They will automatically connect to any solid adjacent blocks. This effectively creates a smooth wall that has posts at the beginning, end, and on corners.

If a torch is placed on top of a cobblestone wall, it will create a post for the torch to rest on. Cobblestone walls are one and a half blocks tall for player and mob collision, but only occupy one block space.

As with fences, this prevents players and mobs from jumping over the walls. If a wall is mined without a pickaxe, it will break and drop nothing.}}
{{BlockSprite|dirt-path}} '''Grass Path'''{{Collapse|content=Grass paths can be created by using a shovel on grass. Placing a block on top of a path or breaking it will transform it to regular dirt. Grass paths can be found naturally generating in villages whenever pathways replace grass blocks.

While these paths are primarily used for decoration, hostile mobs cannot spawn on top of them!}}{{BlockSprite|orange-concrete}} '''Concrete'''{{Collapse|content=Concrete is a solid block that comes in sixteen different dye colours. Its vibrant colours make it a great decorative block! Concrete is formed when concrete powder comes in contact with water or lava while in block form.

If it is mined without anything other than a pickaxe, it will break and drop nothing.}}{{BlockSprite|orange-concrete-powder}} '''Concrete Powder'''

{{Collapse|content=Affected by the laws of gravity, concrete powder is a solid block that comes in sixteen different dye colours. It is crafted from dye, sand, and gravel. When it comes in contact with water or lava while in its block form, it turns into concrete!}}{{BlockSprite|Dried kelp block}} '''Dried Kelp Block'''{{Collapse
|content=
Dried kelp blocks can be crafted from nine pieces of dried kelp. As they can also be crafted back into their original form, this makes dried kelp blocks a compact way to store large amounts of dried kelp! However, dried kelp blocks are primarily used as a 

fuel in furnaces. Each block lasts for 200 seconds and is capable of smelting 20 items!
}}{{BlockSprite|end-rod}} '''End Rod'''{{Collapse|content=End rods are solid, decorative light sources that emit white particles. They have a light level of 14, equal to that of torches. They generate naturally all over end cities, which are located on the outer islands of the End.

Inside some end city towers, they are placed sideways so that players can use them to parkour to the top. You can collect end rods by any tool or block, or you can craft them by combining popped chorus fruit and blaze rods.}}{{BlockSprite|white-glazed-terracotta}} '''Glazed'''

{{Collapse|content=Have you ever looked at the walls and flooring of your home and thought it looked too plain? Glazed terracotta is a colourful decorative block which comes in 16 different colours. It can be obtained by smelting dyed terracotta in a furnace.

Depending on how you place it, glazed terracotta can create a variety of different repeating patterns and designs! Psychedelic!}}{{BlockSprite|Oak Fence}} '''Fence'''{{Collapse
|content=
Fences are decorative blocks that are centered on top of the blocks they are placed on. They will automatically connect to any solid adjacent blocks. Fences have a collision box of one and a half for player and mobs, but they only occupy one block space.

This prevents players from jumping over the walls. Fences can be crafted from oak, spruce, birch, acacia, jungle, or dark oak wood, aswell as nether brick!
}}{{BlockSprite|flower-pot}} '''Flower Pot'''

{{Collapse|content=Flower pots are decorative blocks that can hold flowers, mushrooms, saplings, and plants. You can craft a flower pot from three bricks. Alternatively, you can find them holding red mushrooms in witch huts, holding cacti in the basement of igloos,

or holding various flowers and saplings in woodland mansions. So go on and beautify your dirt hit by bringing a small piece of nature inside.}}{{BlockSprite|glass}} '''Glass'''

{{Collapse|content=Glass is a decorative and functional block that can be created by smelting sand or red sand. Unless it is broken with a Silk Touch tool, it will shatter and drop nothing.

Glass can be crafted into a number of useful items, including glass bottles, end crystals, and beacons! Of course you can always just use it to add windows to your home!
Now you can appreciate the beauty of the outdoors from the comfort of your home!}}{{BlockSprite|white-stained-glass}} '''Stained Glass'''

{{Collapse|content=Stained glass is a decorative transparent block. It is a coloured variant of regular glass.  Unless it is broken with a Silk Touch tool, it will drop nothing. While it cannot be used in place of regular glass in crafting recipes,

it can be crafted into stained glass panes!}}{{BlockSprite|white-stained-glass-pane}} '''Stained Panes'''
{{Collapse|content=Stained glass panes are transparent blocks rafted from stained glass blocks. They are a much more efficient alternative to glass blocks as you can obtain 16 stained glass panes by crafting 6 stained glass panes together. If they are placed without anything on

their sides, they will appear as thin vertical columns. However, they will automatically connect to other panes placed adjacent to them. As with other glass, unless they are broken with a Silk Touch tool, they will shatter and drop nothing.}}{{BlockSprite|ladder}} '''Ladder'''

{{Collapse|content=Up. Down. Up. Down? When placed on the side of other blocks, ladders allow the players to climb walls both vertically and horizontally! Three ladders can be crafted from seven sticks.

Grabbing onto a ladder while falling will negate any fall damage. However, if you land on the top edge of a ladder, you will take fall damage as normal!}}{{BlockSprite|block-of-lapis-lazuli}} '''Lapis Block'''
{{Collapse|content=A lapis lazuli block is a purely decorative mineral block that is crafted from 9 pieces of lapis lazuli. As with lapis lazuli ore, lapis lazuli blocks can only be mined with a stone, iron, or diamond pickaxe.

While there is no crafting use for lapis lazuli blocks, at least it is a handy way for keeping your piles of lapis lazuli neat and tidy! While you‚Äôre exploring, make sure that you check the center of illager statues!

These structures, which generate in woodland mansions, have a lapis lazuli blocks within!}}
{{BlockSprite|nether-bricks}} '''Nether Bricks'''
{{Collapse|content=Nether bricks generate in the Nether, where they make up the structure of nether fortresses. Red Nether bricks are decorative variants that can only be obtained through crafting by combining nether brick with nether wart.

Nether bricks can be mined with any pickaxe. Don‚Äôt feel like finding a nether fortress to obtain Nether bricks? Make your own by smelting netherrack in a furnace!}}
{{BlockSprite|oak-planks}} '''Planks'''

{{Collapse|content=Crafted from logs, and required to make a crafting table, planks are common and important blocks used in many crafting recipes! There are six types: oak, spruce, birch, acacia, and dark oak

While they can be broken by hand, using an axe is significantly faster.}}{{BlockSprite|polished-diorite}} '''Polished Stones'''

{{Collapse|content=There are three types of polished stone: polished andesite, polished diorite, and polished granite.  By crafting together four of the same stone blocks, you will receive four of their polished variants.

These decorative blocks can be used interchangeably with their non-polished variants in crafting recipes.}}{{BlockSprite|chiseled-sandstone}} '''Chiseled''' 

{{Collapse|content=Chiseled sandstone is a decorative block that generates naturally in desert temples. It can also be crafted from two sandstone slabs. From above, it looks the same as regular sandstone.

But, if you take a closer look at its sides, you‚Äôll notice the creeper faces etched into it! Ssssss!}}{{BlockSprite|white-wool}} '''Wool'''
{{Collapse|content=Wool is a block that can be harvested from sheep. Another way to obtain wool is by crafting together four string. Wool can be dyed in any of the sixteen different dye colours.

White, light grey, grey, black, brown, and pink wool can be found naturally on sheep in the wild. All other colours will require you to use dye. When you use shears on an adult sheep, it will drop 1-3 wool.

Sheep will regrow their wool after eating grass. If you kill a sheep that has not been sheared, it will drop one wool upon death. While wool blocks can be broken with anything, shears are the fastest method of breaking wool.}}{{BlockSprite|Sandstone Slab}} '''Slabs'''{{Collapse
|content=
Slabs are half-versions of their respective blocks. Slabs can be placed on the top half or bottom half of a block. This makes them very useful for decorative purposes!

If two slabs of the same type are placed in the same block space, they will form a double slab. Double slabs act as a single block when broken. As a result, breaking one slab will break the double slab and drop two slabs.

Keep in mind that wood slabs can be broken successfully with anything, but all other types require a pickaxe!
}}{{BlockSprite|slime-block}} '''Slime Block'''
{{Collapse|content=A slime block is a semi-transparent block that you can bounce on! How high you bounce is directly relative to how far you fall before bouncing off of the slime blocks. If you try to jump when you come in contact with a slime block,

you will jump normally instead of bouncing higher. Regardless of how far you fall, you will not take any fall damage unless you sneak upon landing. If you cover slime blocks in carpet, they will retain their bouncy nature.

Slime blocks can be crafted from 9 slime balls. They can also be crafted back into slime balls. This make slime blocks a compact way to store slime balls if you ever find yourself with an excessive amount of slime!

Similar to soul sand, your movement speed will be slowed when you walk over a slime block.}}
{{BlockSprite|oak-stairs}} '''Stairs'''
{{Collapse|content=Stairs are blocks that allow players and mobs to ascend and descend blocks without jumping. They also have a lot of decorative potential! Stairs can be placed in many different orientations depending on which direction you are facing when you place them.

You can also attach stairs to create inner and outer corners. Wood stairs can be broken successfully with anything, but all other types require a pickaxe!}}
{{BlockSprite|stripped-oak-log}} '''Stripped Logs'''

{{Collapse|content=Stripped logs are variants of logs that are obtained by using an axe on a log. This is only a visual change, as stripped logs can be used interchangeably with regular logs in all crafting recipes. It comes in six species: oak, spruce, birch, jungle, acacia

and dark oak}}{{BlockSprite|stripped-oak-wood}} '''Stripped Wood'''

{{Collapse|content=Stripped wood is a variant of wood that is obtained by using an axe on a block of wood. It has the stripped wood bark texture on all six sides. This is only a visual change, as stripped wood can be used interchangeably with regular wood in

all crafting recipes. It comes in six species: oak, spruce, birch, jungle, acacia and, and dark oak.}}{{BlockSprite|Oak wood}} '''Wood'''{{Collapse
|content=
Wood is a block that has the log's bark texture on all six of its sides. It comes in six species: oak, spruce, jungle, acacia, and dark oak. Four logs can be crafted together to make three wood.

This is only a visual change as the wood can be used interchangeably with logs in all crafting recipes.
}}{{BlockSprite|stone-bricks}} '''Stone Bricks'''
{{Collapse|content=Stone bricks are a decorative block that comes in four variants: stone bricks, cracked stone bricks, mossy stone bricks, and chiseled stone bricks. Stone bricks can be crafted from four stone.

They generate naturally in strongholds, igloos, and underwater ruins. If they are mined with anything other than a pickaxe, they will break and drop nothing. Be careful while mining out bricks in strongholds!

Silverfish have the ability to enter and hide in any variant of stone bricks! This creates an infested variant of the corresponding block type.}}

=== Biomedomes ===
{{BiomeSprite|badlands plateau}} '''Badlands Plateau'''{{Collapse
|content=
Badland plateaus are rare dry and warm biomes. They feature large hills comrpised of layered terracotta. The tops of these hills flatten out into plateaus that are typically covered in dead bushes.

The sides of the plateau can occasionally reveal exposed mineshafts!
}}
{{BiomeSprite|Birch Forest}} '''Birch Forest'''{{Collapse
|content=
If you like birch trees, then this is the biome for you! As you may have guessed, a birch forest is a biome that is filled with a forest of birch!

Birch forests are a part of the temperate and lush biome family. Unlike regular forests, wolves will not spawn in birch forests.
}}
{{BiomeSprite|Dark Forest}} '''Dark Forest'''{{Collapse
|content=
It sure is dark in here! With a thick canopy of leaves, dark forests are a part of the temperate and lush biome family. As the dark oak trees generate so closely together, it becomes dark enough for hostile mobs to spawn during the day!

Huge mushrooms can also grow amongst the dark oaks.

There is an extremely rare chance that a [[woodland mansion]] will generate within a dark forest! This is the only biome that woodland mansions can appear.
}}
{{BiomeSprite|Desert}} '''Desert'''{{Collapse
|content=
Deserts are common, dry and warm biomes that are usually vast, barren, and lifeless. Deserts were among the first biomes added to the game!

Passive mobs do not spawn and trees do not grow in the desert, making it a challenging biome to survive in at the beginning of the game.

Cacti and dead bushes are naturally generated within the terrain.

Deserts make up for their barrenness by generating a number of different structures within them! These include villages, fossils, desert wells, and desert temples!
}}
{{BiomeSprite|The End}} '''The End'''{{Collapse
|content=
It may be the End, but it isn't the end! The End is a dark, space-like dimension floating in the void. It can be accessed by entering an End portal gateway portal found in strongholds.

The End's central island serves as the main platform for your boss fight with the ender dragon. Large obsidian pillars and end crystals generate naturally on the central island. There is no way to exit the End unless you die or defeat the ender dragon!

Planning on making the End your home? If you place a bed, it will create an explosion that is 25% stronger than TNT. Yikes!

Other than the ender dragon, endermen are the only other residents of the End's main island.
}}
{{BiomeSprite|forest}} '''Forest'''{{Collapse
|content=
Composed of oak and birch trees, forest biomes are a part of the temperate and lush biome family. With an abundance of wood and mild terrain, forest biomes are often preferred by beginners!

Wolves rarely spawn in forest biomes, making forests the only other biome aside from taigas where wolves can spawn!
}}
{{BiomeSprite|frozen ocean}} '''Frozen Ocean'''{{Collapse
|content=
Frozen oceans have dark purple water. Like other cold ocean biomes, frozen oceans have a seafloor composed of gravel. The ocean is completely barren as nether seagrass nor kelp generates naturally.

The most prominent features of frozen oceans are the large icebergs made of snow blocks, packed ice, and blue ice that frequently generate on the surface of the water.

Polar bears and strays are capable of spawning on those icebergs. Salmon, squid, and drowned are the only aquatic mobs that can spawn in the water in frozen oceans.

Frozen oceans will never generate directly next to land. There will always be at least 32 blocks of a cold ocean bordering it if it happens to generate near land!
}}
{{BiomeSprite|Frozen River}} '''Frozen River'''{{Collapse
|content=
Characterized by the icy river winding throughout, frozen river biomes only generate when a river biome enters or comes in contact with a snowy tundra biome.

Frozen rivers are part of the snowy biome family.

Despite the covering of ice over the river, salmon and drowned are still capable of spawning underwater. At night, strays will also spawn above the ice.
}}
{{BiomeSprite|old-growth-spruce-taiga}} '''Giant Spruce'''{{Collapse
|content=
Similar to the taiga biome, giant spruce taiga biomes are covered in spruce trees. However, unlike regular taigas, giant spruce trees now grow beside the normal spruce trees!

Mossy cobblestone boulders are scattered throughout the biome, along with patches of podzol, dirt, and coarse dirt.

This rare biome can be difficult to differentiate from the giant tree taiga biome, but you can tell which biome you are in by looking at the leaves of the giant spruce trees!

If the spruce leaves only grow at the top of the trunk, you are in the giant tree taiga, not a giant spruce taiga!
}}
{{BiomeSprite|Ice Spikes}} '''Ice Spikes'''{{Collapse
|content=
Characterized by large spikes of packed ice and packed 'ice lakes', ice spikes are a rare variation of the snowy tundra biome.

While most of the ice spikes are 10 to 20 blocks tall, some of the other spikes can reach over 50 blocks in height!

As all grass blocks have been replaced by snow blocks in this biome, no passive mobs other than rabbits and polar bears are able to spawn. At night, strays will spawn as well.


}}
{{BiomeSprite|windswept hills}} '''Mountains'''{{Collapse
|content=
Cliffs, peaks, valleys, waterfalls, and more! Mountain biomes stretch high into the sky, reaching heights of Y level 130 and even higher!

With very few trees, this cold biome is grassy, but areas above Y level 92 are dusted with snow.

Mountains are the only biomes where emerald ore and silverfish can be found naturally!

Aside from savannas, mountains are the only bimes where llamas will spawn.
}}
{{BiomeSprite|mushroom fields}} '''Mushroom Fields'''{{Collapse
|content=
What is that strange land on the horizon?

Mushroom fields are rare biomes that spawn in oceans as islands, completely isolated from any other landmasses.

As the ground is covered in mycelium instead of grass, mushrooms are ablt to grow in full sunlight! It is also one of the few biomes where huge mushrooms generate naturally.

While secluded, these biomes are very safe to explore, as mooshrooms are the only mobs that spawn in mushroom fields! Even the usual hostile mobs do not spawn at night!
}}
{{BiomeSprite|Nether wastes}} '''The Nether'''{{Collapse
|content=
The Nether is a molten, hell-like dimension that is full of fire, lava, and dangerous mobs! In order to travel to the Nether, you must construct a nether portal in the Overworld.

The terrain of the Nether is almost entirely made up of netherrack and vast expanses of lava. Clusters of glowstone dangle from the ceiling and mushrooms grow abundantly on the ground.

Soul sand and dangerous patches of floating gravel will also generate throughout the Nether. Near the oceans of lava, you can find patches of magma blocks.

Nether fortresses are the Nether's only naturally generated structures. While they provide valuable loot, be careful as they are also the only place where blazes and wither skeletons spawn!

Feel like mining? Nether quartz can be found scattered around the netherrack. It is the only mineral ore that can be found in the Nether.

Traveling through the Nether may be dangerous, but it is great for fast travel! For every block you travel in the Nether, you travel eight blocks in the Overworld!
}}
{{BiomeSprite|ocean}} '''Ocean'''{{Collapse
|content=
Row, row, row your boat! 
Seriously, don't forget your boat! Oceans are vast expanses of water that can cover large swatches of the Minecraft world.

Covered in seagrass and kelp, the seafloor is mostly made up of gravel, although some clay, dirt, and sand patches will generate in shallow water. The seafloor can be fairly hilly, featuring multiple peaks, valleys, and ravines.

If a peak extends above sea level, it forms an island!

Aquatic mobs, such as drowned, fish, squid, and dolphins, frequently spawn within ocean biomes.
}}
{{EnvSprite|outer islands}} '''Outer Islands'''{{Collapse
|content=
As with the rest of the End, the outer islands are made entirely from endstone. Endermen also spawn throughout the outer islands. The outer islands of the End are broken down into multiple smaller biomes: end midlands, end highlands, small end islands and end barrens.

End cities, chorus plants, and end gateway portals generate in the end midlands and highlands biomes. These two biomes are also the only places where shulkers generate.

The small end islands make up the mostly empty expanse that lies between larger islands. It is populated with smaller, circular islands.

The end barrens biome can be found on the rims of larger islands. This biome has steep cliffs that drop into the void. Watch your step!
}}
{{BiomeSprite|Savanna}} '''Savanna'''{{Collapse
|content=
Savannas are common dry and warm biomes that typically generate bordering deserts and plains. As savannas have a warm climate, it will never rain in one!

These relatively flat biomes are the only biomes where acacia trees generate naturally.
Appropriately, the villages that generate in savannas are built from acacia logs and planks. Although they are less common, oak trees can also be found in savannas.

Aside from mountains, savannas are the only biomes where llamas will spawn. As horses also spawn in savannas, this makes savannas the only biome where both llamas and horses spawn!
}}
{{BiomeSprite|Snowy Taiga}} '''Snowy Taiga'''{{Collapse
|content=
The snowy taiga biome is a mostly flat biome that is covered in large expanses of spruce trees and snow. Snowy taigas are part of the snowy biome family.

Snowy taigas are one of the few biomes where wolves will spawn. They are also one of the two biomes where you can find naturally generated igloos!
}}
{{BiomeSprite|Snowy Plains}} '''Snowy Tundra'''{{Collapse
|content=
The snowy tundra biome is a flat and expansive biome that is covered in snow.

Snowy tundras are part of the snowy biome family. They are one of the two biomes where igloos are naturally generated.

Very few trees are generated in snowy tundras, making it difficult to acquire wood, and all water sources that are exposed to the sky freeze over time.

Other than rabbits and polar bears, no passive mobs are able to spawn. However, strays are able to spawn at night.

Due to all of these harsh conditions, initial survival in snowy tundra biomes provide more of a challenge compared to other biomes!
}}
{{BiomeSprite|Swamp}} '''Swamp'''{{Collapse
|content=
What are you doing in my swamp?!
Characterized by a mix of flat, dry areas and shallow pools of grey-green water with floating lily pads, swamps are a part of the temperate and lush biome family.

As the water is so shallow, clay can be found abundantly. Mushrooms can also be found growing beneath the vine-covered trees.

While there are no ogres in these swamps, slimes will spawn naturally within swamp biomes. As slimes spawn even more commonly during full moons and drowned are capable of spawning underwater, swamps become very dangerous at night!
}}
{{BiomeSprite|taiga}} '''Taiga'''{{Collapse
|content=
The taiga biome is a mostly flat, but slightly hilly, cold biome covered in a forest of spruce trees.

Villages are able to generate in taiga biomes, and the houses in these villages will be built from spruce wood. Wolves and rabbits can also spawn in this biome.

With an abundance of wood, mild terrain, and useful passive mobs, taigas are convenient biomes to live in - as long as you don't mind the cold!
}}
{{BiomeSprite|warm ocean}} '''Warm Ocean'''{{Collapse
|content=
Warm oceans are beautiful and colorful biomes, where coral reefs of various blue, pink, red, purple, and yellow coral generate naturally. If you take the time to explore, you will find schools of tropical fish and pufferfish swimming around!

Warm oceans have light green water. The ocean floor is covered in sand and sea grass. You can also find sea pickles scattered throughout the coral. Kelp does not generate in warm oceans.

Wamr oceans will never generate directly next to land. There will always be at least 32 blocks of a lukewarm ocean bordering it if it happens to generate near land!

If any underwater ruins are generated, they will be composed of sand instead of the stone that makes up the underwater ruins of cold ocean biomes.
}}

=== Mob Gardens ===

==== Passive Mobs ====
{{EntitySprite|mule}} '''Mule'''
{{Collapse|content=Mules are tamable mobs that can be ridden when tamed. Unlike horses and donkeys, mules do not spawn in the wild. They can only be spawned by cross-breeding a horse with a donkey.

Mules spawn with three assigned ‚Äòequine stats‚Äô for their health, maximum movement speed, and jump strength. When a mule foal is bred, it will be untamed. It will also inherit some of its parents‚Äô stats! Mules cannot be bred with other mules

Like donkeys, tamed mules can be equipped with saddles and chests.

Feeding a mule will restore its health, speed up the growth of foals, and increase the temper of untamed mules. They can be fed sugar, wheat, apples, golden carrots, golden apples, and hay bales.

When killed, mules will drop 0-2 leather. If they were equipped with a chest or saddle, they will drop this equipment as well.}}


{{EntitySprite|pig}} '''Pig''' (by OinkWorks)

{{Collapse|content=Oink! Pigs are common passive mobs that spawn in the Overworld. Pigs will follow any player carrying a carrot, carrot on a stick, potato, or beetroot. Pigs can be bred with carrots, potatoes, and beetroot.

If you put a saddle on a pig, you can ride it and join it as it wanders randomly throughout the world! Aimless travel not your thing?

If you have a carrot on a stick, you can control where the saddled pig goes! Wait! What‚Äôs a zombie pigman doing in the overworld?

When struck by lightning or hit by a trident with the Channeling enchantment during a thunderstorm, pigs will turn into zombie pigmen!

When an adult pig is killed, it will drop 1-3 raw porkchop. If it is killed by fire damage,it will drop cooked porkchop instead of raw porkchop. If it was saddled, it will drop the saddle.}}


{{EntitySprite|salmon}} '''Salmon'''

{{Collapse|content=Salmon are common passive mobs found in oceans and rivers. Salmon appear underwater from Y level 12 to 32 in cold and frozen oceans, as well as their deep variants. Unlike other fish types, they will also spawn in normal and frozen rivers.

When killed, they will drop 1 raw salmon. There is a 5% chance that they will also drop 1 bone meal on Java Edition, or a 25% chance they will drop 1-2 bones on Bedrock and Legacy Console editions.

If you use a water bucket on a salmon, you can collect it and obtain a bucket of salmon. Salmon collected and placed with buckets will not despawn naturally. Salmon, like other fish, cannot survive out of water.

They will flop around on their side before they suffocate to death.

<nowiki>:</nowiki>(}}


{{EntitySprite|white-sheep}} '''Sheep''' (by WoolWorks)

{{Collapse|content=Baaa! Sheep are passive mobs that spawn on grass blocks in the Overworld. There is a majority of sheep are white, with an 81.836% chance of spawning. The light grey, grey, and black sheep each have a 5% chance of spawning.

Brown sheep are uncommon and have a 3% chance of spawning. The rarest of tall is the pink sheep which only have a 0.164% chance of spawning!

When you use shears on an adult sheep, it will yield 1-3 wool. Sheep can be dyed any of the 16 dye colours, and sheared wool will match the colour of the sheep.

Sheep can be bred with wheat. If the parents have compatible wool colours that can be combined into a third dye colour, the resulting lamb will be a mix of their colours.

If not, the lamb will be the same colour as one of the two parents.

A regular sheep too boring for you? By naming a sheep ‚Äújeb_‚Äù, you will turn it into a rainbow sheep with wool that cycles smoothly through the different colours!

Alas, this is only a visual effect and it will drop its actual wool colour if sheared or killed. When killed, a sheep will drop one wool matching its colours if it has not already been sheared.

It will also drop 1-2 pieces of raw mutton. If it is killed by fire damage, it will drop cooked mutton instead of raw mutton.}}


{{EntitySprite|squid}} '''Squid'''

{{Collapse|content=Squid are common passive mobs that spawn in water between Y level 46 and sea level. When the world is generated, they can be found in any biome. Afterwards, however, they will only spawn in rivers, beach variants, and ocean biomes.

When killed, a squid will drop 1x3 ink sacs. Squid cannot survive out of water.

If they find themselves on land, they will eventually suffocate to death. If they are attacked, squid will release a cloud of black ink and swim away rapidly in the opposite direction.

Guardians will also attack and kill squid. Strange Fact: in the Java Edition Beta, it was possible to milk a squid and obtain a bucket of milk! Alas, this is no longer possible. #SquidMilk}}


{{EntitySprite|tropical-fish}} '''Tropical Fish'''

{{Collapse|content=Just keep swimming! Tropical fish are common passive mobs found in oceans. Tropical fish spawn in lukewarm, warm, and deep lukewarm oceans from Y level 12 to 32. In Bedrock Edition, they only spawn in oceans from Y biomes.

With a whopping 3,584 different variants of tropical fish, there are far too many to list! When killed, they will drop 1 raw tropical fish. Regardless of the tropical fish killed, they will drop item will always appear as a clownfish.

There is a 5% chance that they will also drop 1 bone meal on Java Edition, or a 25% chance they will drop 1-2 bones on Bedrock and Legacy Console editions.

If you use a water bucket on a tropical fish, you can collect it and obtain a bucket of tropical fish. If you take a closer look at these buckets, you‚Äôll see that each tropical fish has a name!

Tropical fish collected and placed with buckets will not respawn naturally. Tropical fish, like other fish, cannot survive out of water. They will flop around on their side before they suffocate to death.}}{{EntitySprite|turtle}} '''Turtle'''
{{Collapse|content=Turtles are common mobs that can survive both on land and in water. They typically spawn in the Overworld on beaches, but not in snowy variants or on stone shores.

Turtles will follow a player holding seagrass. If two turtles are fed seagrass, they will enter love mode. One of the turtles will hold an egg in its inventory and make its way back to its home beach.

A turtle‚Äôs home beach is where it originally hatched or spawned. Once it returns, home, it will find a sand block to lay 1-4 eggs on. Turtle eggs will undergo three stages before they hatch into baby turtles.

Baby turtles can only hatch at night if their eggs are on the sand. If you were to use a Silk Touch tool on turtle eggs, you can relocate the turtle eggs and effectively set their home beach wherever you want!

When a baby turtle grows up into its adult form, it drops one scute.

When killed, an adult turtle will drop 0-2 pieces of seagrass.}}{{EntitySprite|Bat}} '''Bats'''{{Collapse
|content=
Na na na na na na na na na! Bats are flying mobs that spawn in caves. With their little squeaks, they add atmosphere to caves. When they are killed, they do not drop any items or experience.
}}

==== Neutral Mobs ====

==== Hostile Mobs ====
{{EntitySprite|Creeper}} '''Creeper'''{{Collapse
|content=
Ssssssssssss... Ah, the dreaded sound of a creeper hissing behind you! True to their namesake, creepers will silently creep up on unsuspecting players before hissing and exploding.

Naturally spawning in the Overworld, these iconic mobs drop 0-2 [[gunpowder]] when killed. However, if a crepeer is killed by a skeleton or stray, it will drop a random music disc!

If a creeper is struck by lightning, it becomes charged, amplifying its explosion power!
}}

=== The Museum of Redstone ===
{{BlockSprite|redstone-dust-t-left}} '''AND Gate'''{{Collapse
|content=
AND Gate.

Once you've mastered the basics you can build some pretty crazy contraptions with redstone! This is an example of an AND gate.

To power the lamp, both levers need to be turned on at the same time. This particular logic gate has been used a lot behind the scenes to power this puzzle!
}}
{{BlockSprite|Stone button}} '''Buttons'''{{Collapse
|content=
Buttons.

Everyone loves to press a good button. Pressing a button in Minecraft will only output a redstone signal for a short period of time however wooden button can be activated for longer periods by shooting an arrow at them. Take a shot!
}}
{{BlockSprite|redstone comparator}} '''Comparator 1'''{{Collapse
|content=
Comparator Inventory Detection.

A comparator placed next to a block with an inventory (such as a chest or hopper) will output a signal based on how full the inventory is.

Fill up this chest with enough items to turn on the lamp.
}}
{{BlockSprite|redstone comparator on}} '''Comparator 2'''{{Collapse
|content=
Hopper inventory fullness detection.

Here we have a hopper and a comparator detecting how full it is. There's also a bit of redstone logic thrown in there, but don't worry too much about that.

The comparator is detecting how full the hopper is so you need to add some items to create an output. Not enough items and the signal will be too weak, too many items and the signal will go too far and disable the redstone clock.

Try and work out the right amount of items to put into the hopper.

Hint: if in doubt, try half. Always go halfsies.
}}
{{BlockSprite|redstone comparator off}} '''Comparator 3'''{{Collapse
|content=
Normal comparator.

A comparator can look into block inventories using the input on its back (back input), but it also has an input on the side (side input).

The comparator will compare the two - if the side input is more powerful than the back input, then the comparator will not output anything. If it is as or less powerful than the back input, it will output a signal of the same strength as the back input.
}}
{{BlockSprite|redstone comparator}} '''Comparator 4'''{{Collapse
|content=
Comparator in subtract mode.

Check out the normal comparator device before giving this one a go!

Comparators have a clever little thing called 'subtract mode'.

In subtract mode the comparator takes the signal going in the back (closest to the redstone block) and subtracts the value of the redstone signal going in the side.

One of the levers will give the subtract comparator just enough power so that the redstone signal will travel the exact distance it needs to!
}}
{{BlockSprite|detector rail on}} '''Detector Rails'''{{Collapse
|content=
Detector Rails.

Detector rails are minecart rails which can detect if something is on top of them, essential for epic roller-coaster building! You might have noticed them in the tunnel that you first travelled through to get here.
}}
{{BlockSprite|lever}} '''Lever'''{{Collapse
|content=
One of the simplest redstone devices, levers are a redstone power source that you can turn 'on' or 'off'.
}}
{{BlockSprite|daylight detector}} '''Light Detector'''{{Collapse
|content=
Daylight detectors.

Daylight detectors detect the brightness of the sun and will output a signal based on this brightness.

They can be connected to a redstone lamp, and with some clever tinkering they can be made to turn on the lamp automatically at night, and turn it off during the morning - it's always good to save energy!
}}
{{BlockSprite|redstone repeater}} '''Locking Repeater'''{{Collapse
|content=
Locking repeater.

Repeaters are handy little blocks which can delay a signal for an amount of time, but they can also be used to 'lock' signals in one state. If you power one repeater with another from the side, that repeater will become 'locked', and

remember the input it had before it was 'locked'. You can then change the back input, and the output from the repeater will not change.

This machine has one repeater pointing into the side of another, which can therefore be locked. To power the lamp you will need the output from this repeater to be off, whilst keeping the lever from its back input to stay on.

If you do this in the correct order, the repeater will be locked whilst in its off state, and the lamp will turn on!
}}
{{BlockSprite|pressure plates}} '''Pressure Plates'''{{Collapse
|content=
Pressure plates.

Minecraft has a few different types of pressure plates. Wood and stone pressure plates will emit a full signal with any item, player or creature is on them.

'Weighted' pressure plates will output a signal based on the number of items or creatures on them. These come in two types, 'light' and 'heavy'.

Heavy weighted pressure plates (iron) require more items or creatures than light weighted pressure plates (gold) to output the same strength signal.
}}
{{ItemSprite|Chain boots}} '''Redstone Cannon'''{{Collapse
|content=
No wonder this dangerous contraption has been moved into the museum attic...

It still works, but make sure you grab a pair of special boots before giving it a try!
}}
{{EntitySprite|Sheep}} '''Redstone Grove'''{{Collapse
|content=
The magical trees of Redstone Grove. 
Sway and blow in the voltaic breeze. 
Alas the sheep that there did graze,
Did then absorb too many electrical rays!
}}
{{BlockSprite|Redstone torch}} '''Redstone Torch'''{{Collapse
|content=
Redstone Torch.

A redstone torch can be used to activate redstone devices but it also can be used to invert a redstone signal. If the block it is placed on is powered it will turn off and if it is unpowered it will turn on.
}}
{{BlockSprite|Slime Block}} '''Slime Blocks'''{{Collapse
|content=
Slime blocks.

Sticky pistons can push and pull one block connected to it. When a slime block is connected to a piston, it will also push and block any block connected to it (except obsidian and bedrock).

Flick the levers at the base of the three pistons to make the redstone signal flow through the device and reach the redstone lamp. You may want to jump on top of the device to get a better view!
}}
{{BlockSprite|Piston side left}} '''T Flip-Flop 1'''{{Collapse
|content=
Toggle Flip-Flop.

This may sound like some beach-appropriate footwear, but this is a serious piece of electronic equipment so stop dreaming about sand, sea and sunshine and listen up!

This device works like a lever, switching from an on-state to an off-state with a simple pulse input. Although it works like a lever, it is activated with a button input. Pressing the button will switch it between on and off.
}}
{{BlockSprite|Piston side right}} '''T Flip-Flop 2'''{{Collapse
|content=
Chained Toggle Flip-Flop.

Now we're getting fancy. Try fixing the toggle flip device if you have not already before attempting this!

This device is three 'toggle flip-flops' connected together with one button input. Each one will scroll through the combinations of the next one giving a total of 8 ways to light the lamps.

Only one of those combinations will light up all three lamps, which is what you need to do!
}}
{{BlockSprite|Piston}} '''T Flip-Flop'''{{More info}}{{Collapse
|content=
This Toggle Flip-Flop design is much more complex than the Java version.

There is a quirk of Java redstone that does not exist in the Bedrock edition (this version) which means that the Java design is unpredictable.

Thanks to /u/PC_Screen for your Reddit post that pointed me in the right direction of observers which solves this issue.
}}
{{BlockSprite|Tripwire hook}} '''Tripwire'''{{Collapse
|content=
Tripwire.

A tripwire works like a pressure plate except it is very hard to notice. They can be used to make traps and are used in jungle temples. You can trick this particular trap by placing an item on it!
}}

== Trivia ==
* Players in the world are permanently affected by [[Speed]] II, presumably to help them traverse the large map.
* The Vault's code: 170509, is based off Minecraft's original release date: May 17, 2009.
* The [[Update Aquatic]] is erroneously referred to as the "Aquatic Update," a common mistake.
** Similarly, the [[horse update]] is referred to as the "horses update."
* In the Vault, chests belonging to [[liquid]] blocks are placed within the floor.
* Surrounding the map, every [[splash text]] up to that point is engraved on the floor.
* Many of the descriptive books make references to pop culture, such as the entry on bats beginning on a nod to the theme song of the 1966 [[w:Batman (TV series)|Batman]] television series, and the swamp book containing the line "what are you doing in my swamp," a line associated with the character [[Shrek]].
** Both of those properties would later receive official collaborations with Minecraft, in the form of the [[Batman (world)|Batman]] map and the [[Universal Studios Event]].
